pli-tv-pvr7:46.4.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits through someone else’s speech and clears through someone else’s speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.4.comm: Sp 5.324: Paravācāya āpajjati paravācāya vuṭṭhātīti yāvatatiyakaṁ saṅghādisesaṁ parassa kammavācāya āpajjati, vuṭṭhahantopi parassa parivāsakammavācādīhi vuṭṭhāti, “One commits through someone else’s speech and clears through someone else’s speech: one commits a third announcement offense entailing suspension through someone else’s legal-procedure announcement, and then clears it through someone else’s legal-procedure announcement concerning probation, etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.5.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits by body, but clears by speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.5.comm: Sp 5.324: Kāyadvārikaṁ kāyena āpajjati, desento vācāya vuṭṭhāti, “One commits a body-door offense by body, and one clears it by speech through confession.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.6.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits by speech, but clears by body.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.6.comm: Sp 5.324: Vacīdvārikaṁ vācāya āpajjati, tiṇavatthārake kāyena vuṭṭhāti, “One commits a speech-door offense by speech, and one clears it by body through covering over as if with grass.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.7.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits by body and clears by body.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.7.comm: Sp 5.324: Kāyadvārikaṁ kāyenaāpajjati, tameva tiṇavatthārake kāyena vuṭṭhāti, “One commits a body-door offense by body, and one clears it by body through covering over as if with grass.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.8.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits by speech and clears by speech.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.8.comm: Sp 5.324: Vacīdvārikaṁ vācāya āpajjati, tameva desento vācāya vuṭṭhāti, “One commits a speech-door offense by speech, and one clears it by speech through confession.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.9.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits while sleeping, but clears while awake.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.9.comm: Sp 5.324: Saṅghikamañcassa attano paccattharaṇena anattharato kāyasamphusane lomagaṇanāya āpajjitabbāpattiṁ sahagāraseyyāpattiñca pasutto āpajjati, pabujjhitvā pana āpannabhāvaṁ ñatvā desento paṭibuddho vuṭṭhāti, “For one not covering a bed belonging to the Sangha with his own sheet, an offense is committed through the counting of hairs when the body touches. And the offense of sharing a bed in a house is also committed while sleeping. But having woken up and knowing that one has committed an offense, one clears it by confessing while awake.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.10.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits while awake, but clears while sleeping.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.10.comm: Sp 5.324: Jagganto āpajjitvā pana tiṇavatthārakasamathaṭṭhāne sayanto paṭibuddho āpajjati pasutto vuṭṭhāti nāma, “Having committed an offense while awake and then sleeping in the place where it is settled by covering over as if with grass—this is called ‘one commits while awake, but clears while sleeping’.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.11.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits while sleeping and clears while sleeping.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.11.comm: Sp 5.324: Pacchimapadadvayampi vuttānusāreneva veditabbaṁ, “The last two cases are to be known through conformity with what has been said.” This means that the last two cases follow the example of the first two.

pli-tv-pvr7:46.12.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits while awake and clears while awake.

pli-tv-pvr7:46.13.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits unintentionally, but clears intentionally.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.13.comm: Sp 5.324: Acittakāpattiṁ acittako āpajjati nāma. Pacchā desento sacittako vuṭṭhāti, “An unintentional offense is called committed unintentionally. When confessing it later, one clears it intentionally.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.14.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits intentionally, but clears unintentionally.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.14.comm: Sp 5.324: Sacittakāpattiṁ sacittako āpajjati nāma. Tiṇavatthārakaṭṭhāne sayanto acittako vuṭṭhāti, “An intentional offense is called committed intentionally. When sleeping at the place (they do the legal procedure) of covering over as if with grass, one clears it unintentionally.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.15.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits unintentionally and clears unintentionally.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.15.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesapadadvayampi vuttānusāreneva veditabbaṁ, “The remaining pair, too, is to be understood in accordance with what has been said.” That is, one is to combine each of the two parts of the previous two cases as appropriate to explain this case and the next one.

pli-tv-pvr7:46.16.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits intentionally and clears intentionally.

pli-tv-pvr7:46.17.eng: (1) There are offenses where one confesses an offense while committing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.17.comm: Sp 5.324: Yo sabhāgaṁ āpattiṁ deseti, ayaṁ desanāpaccayā dukkaṭaṁ āpajjanto, “Whoever confesses a shared offense, commits an offense of wrong conduct on account of the confession.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.18.eng: (2) There are offenses where one commits an offense while confessing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.18.comm: Sp 5.324: Yo sabhāgaṁ āpattiṁ deseti, ayaṁ desanāpaccayā dukkaṭaṁ āpajjanto pācittiyādīsu aññataraṁ deseti, tañca desento dukkaṭaṁ āpajjati, “Whoever confesses a shared offense, committing an offense of wrong conduct on account of the confession, if he confesses an offense among the offenses entailing confession etc., in confessing that he commits an offense of wrong conduct.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.19.eng: (3) There are offenses where one clears an offense while committing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.19.comm: Sp 5.324: Taṁ pana dukkaṭaṁ āpajjanto pācittiyādito vuṭṭhāti, “But in committing that offense of wrong conduct, he clears the offense entailing confession, etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.20.eng: (4) There are offenses where one commits an offense while clearing an offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.20.comm: Sp 5.324: Pācittiyādito ca vuṭṭhahanto taṁ āpajjati. Iti ekassa puggalassa ekameva payogaṁ sandhāya “āpattiṁ āpajjanto desetī”ti idaṁ catukkaṁ vuttanti veditabbaṁ, “In clearing the offense entailing confession, etc., he commits that offense. Thus it is to be understood that this fourfold statement was said with reference to just a single effort of a single individual, that is, ‘One confesses an offense while committing an offense’.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.21.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits through action, but clears through non-action.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.21.comm: Sp 5.324: Kammacatukke pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā appaṭinissaggāpattiṁ kammena āpajjati, desento akammena vuṭṭhāti, “In the tetrad on legal procedures, one commits the offense for not giving up a bad view through a legal procedure, but clears it without a legal procedure when confessing it.” Sp-yoj 5.324: Kammenāti samanubhāsanakammena: “Through a legal procedure means through the legal procedure of pressing.” See Bu Pc 68:1.49.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:46.22.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits through non-action, but clears through action.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.22.comm: Sp 5.324: Vissaṭṭhiādikaṁ akammena āpajjati, parivāsādinā kammena vuṭṭhāti, “One commits the offense of emission without a legal procedure, but clears it through the legal procedure of probation, etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.23.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits through action and clears through action.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.23.comm: Sp 5.324: Samanubhāsanaṁ kammeneva āpajjati, kammena vuṭṭhāti, “One commits the offense through a legal procedure of pressing and clears it through a legal procedure.”

pli-tv-pvr7:46.24.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits through non-action and clears through non-action.
pli-tv-pvr7:46.24.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesaṁ akammena āpajjati, akammena vuṭṭhāti, “One commits the rest without a legal procedure and clears them without a legal procedure.”

pli-tv-pvr7:47.1.eng: There are four kinds of ignoble speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:47.2.pli: adiṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, assute sutavāditā, amute mutavāditā, aviññāte viññātavāditā.
pli-tv-pvr7:47.2.eng: (1) saying that one has seen what one has not seen; (2) saying that one has heard what one has not heard; (3) saying that one has sensed what one has not sensed; (4) saying that one has known what one has not known.

pli-tv-pvr7:47.3.eng: There are four kinds of noble speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:47.4.pli: adiṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, assute assutavāditā, amute amutavāditā, aviññāte aviññātavāditā.
pli-tv-pvr7:47.4.eng: (1) saying that one has not seen what one has not seen; (2) saying that one has not heard what one has not heard; (3) saying that one has not sensed what one has not sensed; (4) saying that one has not known what one has not known.

pli-tv-pvr7:47.5.eng: There are four other kinds of ignoble speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:47.6.pli: diṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, sute assutavāditā, mute amutavāditā, viññāte aviññātavāditā.
pli-tv-pvr7:47.6.eng: (1) saying that one has not seen what one has seen; (2) saying that one has not heard what one has heard; (3) saying that one has not sensed what one has sensed; (4) saying that one has not known what one has known.

pli-tv-pvr7:47.7.eng: There are four other kinds of noble speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:47.8.pli: diṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, sute sutavāditā, mute mutavāditā, viññāte viññātavāditā.
pli-tv-pvr7:47.8.eng: (1) saying that one has seen what one has seen; (2) saying that one has heard what one has heard; (3) saying that one has sensed what one has sensed; (4) saying that one has known what one has known.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.1.eng: The monks have four offenses entailing expulsion in common with the nuns. —

pli-tv-pvr7:48.2.eng: The nuns have four offenses entailing expulsion not in common with the monks.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.3.eng: There are four kinds of requisites:
pli-tv-pvr7:48.3.comm: Sp 5.324: Parikkhāracatukke paṭhamo sakaparikkhāro, dutiyo saṅghikova tatiyo cetiyasantako, catuttho gihiparikkhāro, “In the tetrad on requisites, the first is one’s own requisites, the second the requisites of the Sangha, the third what is owned by a shrine, and the fourth the requisites of a householder.” For a dicsussion of the word vibbhamati, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.4.pli: atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo mamāyitabbo paribhuñjitabbo;
pli-tv-pvr7:48.4.eng: (1) There are requisites that should be guarded, taken as a personal possession, and made use of.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.5.pli: atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo mamāyitabbo, na paribhuñjitabbo;
pli-tv-pvr7:48.5.eng: (2) There are requisites that should be guarded and made use of, but not taken as a personal possession.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.5.comm: I translate according to the reading found in SRT: Atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo na mamāyitabbo paribhuñjitabbo. The Pali reading found in the current text does not fit the commentarial explanation that this concerns a requisite belonging to the Sangha, for Sangha requisites cannot be taken as one’s own. So it seems the commentarial explanation must be based on the SRT reading.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.6.pli: atthi parikkhāro rakkhitabbo gopetabbo, na mamāyitabbo na paribhuñjitabbo;
pli-tv-pvr7:48.6.eng: (3) There are requisites that should be guarded, but not taken as a personal possession or made use of.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.7.pli: atthi parikkhāro na rakkhitabbo na gopetabbo, na mamāyitabbo na paribhuñjitabbo.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.7.eng: (4) There are requisites that should neither be guarded, nor taken as a personal possession, nor made use of.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.8.eng: (1) There are offenses one commits in the presence of someone, but clears in their absence.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.8.comm: Sp 5.324: Sammukhācatukke pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā appaṭinissaggāpattiṁ saṅghassa sammukhā āpajjati, vuṭṭhānakāle pana saṅghena kiccaṁ natthīti parammukhā vuṭṭhāti, “In the tetrad on presence, one commits an offense for not giving up a bad view in the presence of the Sangha, but at the time of clearing, one clears it in its absence, thinking, ‘There is no duty for the Sangha’.”

pli-tv-pvr7:48.9.eng: (2) There are offenses one commits in the absence of someone, but clears in their presence.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.9.comm: Sp 5.324: Vissaṭṭhiādikaṁ parammukhā āpajjati, saṅghassa sammukhā vuṭṭhāti, “One commits an offense of emission, etc., in the absence of the Sangha, but clears it in its presence.”

pli-tv-pvr7:48.10.eng: (3) There are offenses one commits in the presence of someone and clears in their presence.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.10.comm: Sp 5.324: Samanubhāsanaṁ saṅghassa sammukhā eva āpajjati, sammukhā vuṭṭhāti, “One commits an offense when pressed in the presence of the Sangha and also clears it in its presence.”

pli-tv-pvr7:48.11.eng: (4) There are offenses one commits in the absence of someone and clears in their absence.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.11.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesaṁ sampajānamusāvādādibhedaṁ parammukhāva āpajjati, parammukhāva vuṭṭhāti, “For the remainder, that is, the category of lying in full awareness, etc., one commits an offense in the absence of the Sangha and also clears it in its absence.”

pli-tv-pvr7:48.12.eng: (1) There are offenses one commits unknowingly, but clears knowingly.
pli-tv-pvr7:48.12.comm: Sp 5.324: Ajānantacatukkaṁ acittakacatukkasadisaṁ, “The tetrad on knowing is similar to the tetrad on unintentional.”

pli-tv-pvr7:48.13.eng: (2) There are offenses one commits knowingly, but clears unknowingly.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.14.eng: (3) There are offenses one commits unknowingly and clears unknowingly.

pli-tv-pvr7:48.15.eng: (4) There are offenses one commits knowingly and clears knowingly.

pli-tv-pvr7:49.1.eng: One commits offenses in four ways:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.2.pli: kāyena āpajjati, vācāya āpajjati, kāyena vācāya āpajjati, kammavācāya āpajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.2.eng: by body, by speech, by body and speech, through a legal procedure. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.3.eng: One commits offenses in four other ways:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.4.eng: in the midst of the Sangha, in the midst of a group, in the presence of an individual, through the appearance of sexual characteristics. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.5.eng: One clears offenses in four ways:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.6.pli: kāyena vuṭṭhāti, vācāya vuṭṭhāti, kāyena vācāya vuṭṭhāti, kammavācāya vuṭṭhāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.6.eng: by body, by speech, by body and speech, through a legal procedure. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.7.eng: One clears offenses in four other ways:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.8.eng: in the midst of the Sangha, in the midst of a group, in the presence of an individual, through the appearance of sexual characteristics. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.9.pli: Saha paṭilābhena purimaṃ jahati, pacchime patiṭṭhāti, viññattiyo paṭippassambhanti, paṇṇattiyo nirujjhanti.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.9.eng: When one gets it: one abandons the former, one is established in the latter, asking for things comes to a stop, rules come to an end. —
pli-tv-pvr7:49.9.comm: Sp 5.324: Sahapaṭilābhacatukke yassa bhikkhuno liṅgaṁ parivattati, so saha liṅgapaṭilābhena paṭhamaṁ uppannavasena seṭṭhabhāvena ca purimaṁ purisaliṅgaṁ jahati, pacchime itthiliṅge patiṭṭhāti, purisakuttapurisākārādivasena pavattā kāyavacīviññattiyo paṭippassambhanti, bhikkhūti vā purisoti vā evaṁ pavattā paṇṇattiyo nirujjhanti, yāni bhikkhunīhi asādhāraṇāni chacattālīsa sikkhāpadāni tehi anāpattiyeva hoti, “In the tetrad on ‘when one gets it’, the characteristics of a monk are changed. Together with the appearance of the characteristics, then, on account of their arising first and being the best, he abandons the former characteristics of a man. He is established in the latter characteristics of a woman. The asking for things by body and speech that happens on account of the ways of a man, etc., that comes to a stop. Expressions used such as ‘monk’ and ‘man’ come to an end. The forty-six training rules of the monks that are not in common with the nuns are now non-offenses.”

pli-tv-pvr7:49.10.pli: Saha paṭilābhena pacchimaṃ jahati, purime patiṭṭhāti, viññattiyo paṭippassambhanti, paṇṇattiyo nirujjhanti.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.10.eng: When one gets it: one abandons the latter, one is established in the former, asking for things comes to a stop, rules come to an end. —
pli-tv-pvr7:49.10.comm: Sp 5.324: Dutiyacatukke pana yassā bhikkhuniyā liṅgaṁ parivattati, sā pacchāsamuppattiyā vā hīnabhāvena vā pacchimanti saṅkhyaṁ gataṁ itthiliṅgaṁ jahati, vuttappakārena purimanti saṅkhyaṁ gate purisaliṅge patiṭṭhāti. … bhikkhunīti vā itthīti vā evaṁ pavattā paṇṇattiyopi nirujjhanti, yāni bhikkhūhi asādhāraṇāni sataṁ tiṁsañca sikkhāpadāni, tehi anāpattiyeva hoti, “In the second tetrad, the characteristics of a nun change. Because of their later arising or because of being inferior, she is reckoned as abandoning the latter female characteristic, and in the said way is reckoned as established in the former characteristics of a man. … Expressions used such as ‘nun’ and ‘woman’ come to an end. The one hundred and thirty training rules of the nuns that are not in common with the monks are now non-offenses.”

pli-tv-pvr7:49.11.eng: There are four kinds of accusing:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.12.pli: sīlavipattiyā codeti, ācāravipattiyā codeti, diṭṭhivipattiyā codeti, ājīvavipattiyā codeti.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.12.eng: one accuses someone for failure in morality, one accuses someone for failure in conduct, one accuses someone for failure in view, one accuses someone for failure in livelihood. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.13.eng: There are four kinds of probation:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.14.eng: probation for concealed offenses, probation for unconcealed offenses, purifying probation, and simultaneous probation. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.15.eng: There are four kinds of trial periods:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.16.eng: trial periods for concealed offenses, trial periods for unconcealed offenses, trial periods for a half-month, and simultaneous trial periods. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.17.eng: There are four things that stop a monk who is undertaking the trial period from counting a particular day toward his trial period:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.18.pli: sahavāso, vippavāso, anārocanā, ūne gaṇe carati.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.18.eng: he stays in the same room as a regular monk; he stays apart from other monks; he doesn’t inform other monks of his status; he travels without a group. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.19.comm: Sp 5.324: Cattāro sāmukkaṁsāti cattāro mahāpadesā, “The four unique things are the four great standards.” For an explanation of the rendering “standard” for sugata, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:49.20.eng: There are four things that need to be received:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.21.eng: ordinary food, post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, and lifetime tonics. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.24.eng: There are four kinds of legal procedures:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.25.eng: procedures consisting of getting permission, procedures consisting of one motion, procedures consisting of one motion and one announcement, or procedures consisting of one motion and three announcements. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.26.eng: There are four other kinds of legal procedures:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.27.pli: adhammena vaggakammaṃ, adhammena samaggakammaṃ, dhammena vaggakammaṃ, dhammena samaggakammaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.27.eng: illegitimate legal procedures done by an incomplete assembly, illegitimate legal procedures done unanimously, legitimate legal procedures done by an incomplete assembly, and legitimate legal procedures done unanimously. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.28.eng: There are four kinds of failure:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.29.eng: failure in morality, failure in conduct, failure in view, and failure in livelihood. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.30.eng: There are four kinds of legal issues:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.31.eng: legal issues arising from disputes, legal issues arising from accusations, legal issues arising from offenses, and legal issues arising from business. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.32.eng: There are four kinds of people who corrupt a gathering:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.33.pli: bhikkhu dussīlo pāpadhammo parisadūsano, bhikkhunī dussīlā pāpadhammā parisadūsanā, upāsako dussīlo pāpadhammo parisadūsano, upāsikā dussīlā pāpadhammā parisadūsanā.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.33.eng: an immoral monk with bad qualities, an immoral nun with bad qualities, an immoral male lay follower with bad qualities, an immoral female lay follower with bad qualities. —

pli-tv-pvr7:49.34.eng: There are four kinds of people who make a gathering shine:

pli-tv-pvr7:49.35.pli: bhikkhu sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo parisasobhano, bhikkhunī sīlavatī kalyāṇadhammā parisasobhanā, upāsako sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo parisasobhano, upāsikā sīlavatī kalyāṇadhammā parisasobhanā.
pli-tv-pvr7:49.35.eng: a moral monk with good qualities, a moral nun with good qualities, a moral male lay follower with good qualities, a moral female lay follower with good qualities.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.1.eng: (1) There are offenses committed by new arrivals, not by residents.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.1.comm: For this tetrad, see Kd 18:1.1.1 and Kd 18:2.1.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.2.eng: (2) There are offenses committed by residents, not by new arrivals.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.3.pli: atthāpatti āgantuko ceva āpajjati āvāsiko ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:50.3.eng: (3) There are offenses committed both by new arrivals and by residents.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.4.pli: atthāpatti neva āgantuko āpajjati, no āvāsiko.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.4.eng: (4) There are offenses committed neither by new arrivals nor by residents.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.5.eng: (1) There are offenses committed by those departing, not by residents.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.5.comm: For this tetrad, see Kd 18:3.1.1 and Kd 18:2.1.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.6.eng: (2) There are offenses committed by residents, not by those departing.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.7.pli: atthāpatti gamiko ceva āpajjati āvāsiko ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:50.7.eng: (3) There are offenses committed both by those departing and by residents.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.8.pli: atthāpatti neva gamiko āpajjati no āvāsiko.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.8.eng: (4) There are offenses committed neither by those departing nor by residents.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.9.pli: Atthi vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, atthi āpattinānattatā no vatthunānattatā, atthi vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca, atthi neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.9.eng: (1) There are rules that have variety in the action that is the basis for the offense, but not in the offense. (2) There are rules that have variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules that have variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. (4) There are rules that have variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.9.comm: Sp 5.324: Vatthunānattatādicatukke catunnaṁ pārājikānaṁ aññamaññaṁ vatthunānattatāva hoti,naāpattinānattatā. Sabbāpi hi sā pārājikāpattiyeva. Saṅghādisesādīsupi eseva nayo. Bhikkhussa ca bhikkhuniyā ca aññamaññaṁ kāyasaṁsagge bhikkhussa saṅghādiseso bhikkhuniyā pārājikanti evaṁ āpattinānattatāva hoti, na vatthunānattatā, ubhinnampi hi kāyasaṁsaggova vatthu. Tathā “lasuṇakkhādane bhikkhuniyā pācittiyaṁ, bhikkhussa dukkaṭa”nti evamādināpettha nayena yojanā veditabbā. Catunnaṁ pārājikānaṁ terasahi saṅghādisesehi saddhiṁ vatthunānattatā ceva āpattinānattatā ca. Evaṁ saṅghādisesādīnaṁ aniyatādīhi. Ādito paṭṭhāya cattāri pārājikāni ekato āpajjantānaṁ bhikkhubhikkhunīnaṁ neva vatthunānattatā no āpattinānattatā, “In the tetrad on ‘variety in the action that is the basis for the offense’, for each of the four offenses entailing expulsion, there is variety in the action that is the basis for the offense but no variety in the offense. For all it is just an offense entailing expulsion. The same method applies to the offenses entailing suspension, etc. Regarding physical contact, each for a monk or a nun, there is an offense entailing suspension for a monk and an offense entailing expulsion for a nun, and thus there is variety in the offense, but not in the action that is the basis for the offense, for both have physical contact as the basis for the action. So, in eating garlic, there is an offense of confession for a nun but an offense of wrong conduct for a monk. Here the meaning is to be understood through this method, etc. For the four offenses entailing expulsion, together with the thirteen offenses entailing suspension, there is variety both in the action that is the basis for the offense and in the offense. Thus it is for the offenses entailing suspension, etc., together with the undetermined offenses, etc. Starting from the four offenses entailing expulsion on one side, for the committing monks and nuns, there is variety neither in the action that is the basis for the offense nor in the offense”

pli-tv-pvr7:50.10.pli: Atthi vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, atthi āpattisabhāgatā no vatthusabhāgatā, atthi vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca atthi neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.10.eng: (1) There are rules where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. (2) There are rules where the offense is shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. (3) There are rules where both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. (4) There are rules where neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.10.comm: Sp 5.324: Vatthusabhāgādicatukke bhikkhussa ca bhikkhuniyā ca kāyasaṁsagge vatthusabhāgatā, no āpattisabhāgatā, catūsu pārājikesu āpattisabhāgatā, no vatthusabhāgatā. Esa nayo saṅghādisesādīsu. Bhikkhussa ca bhikkhuniyā ca catūsu pārājikesu vatthusabhāgatā ceva āpattisabhāgatā ca. Esa nayo sabbāsu sādhāraṇāpattīsu. Asādhāraṇāpattiyaṁ neva vatthusabhāgatā no āpattisabhāgatā, “In the tetrad on ‘where the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, etc.’, regarding physical contact for a monk or a nun, the action that is the basis for the offense is shared, but not the offense. For the four offenses entailing expulsion, the offenses are shared, but not the action that is the basis for the offense. This is the method for the offenses entailing suspension. For the four offenses entailing expulsion of both the monks and the nuns, both the action that is the basis for the offense and the offense are shared. This is the method for all the common offenses. For the offenses that are not in common, neither the action that is the basis for the offense nor the offense is shared.”

pli-tv-pvr7:50.11.pli: Atthāpatti upajjhāyo āpajjati no saddhivihāriko, atthāpatti saddhivihāriko āpajjati no upajjhāyo, atthāpatti upajjhāyo ceva āpajjati saddhivihāriko ca, atthāpatti neva upajjhāyo āpajjati no saddhivihāriko.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.11.eng: (1) There are offenses committed by the preceptor, but not the student. (2) There are offenses committed by the student, but not the preceptor. (3) There are offenses committed by both the preceptor and the student. (4) There are offenses committed by neither the preceptor nor the student.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.11.comm: Sp 5.324: Upajjhāyacatukke saddhivihārikassa upajjhāyena kattabbavattassa akaraṇe āpattiṁ upajjhāyo āpajjati, no saddhivihāriko upajjhāyassa kattabbavattaṁ akaronto saddhivihāriko āpajjati, no upajjhāyo; sesaṁ ubhopi āpajjanti, asādhāraṇaṁ ubhopi nāpajjanti, “In the tetrad on the preceptor, the preceptor commits an offense in not doing the duties to be done by a preceptor, not the student. The student commits an offense in not doing the duties to be done towards a preceptor, not the preceptor. The rest are committed by both. Offenses not in common between the monks and the nuns are committed by neither.”

pli-tv-pvr7:50.12.pli: Atthāpatti ācariyo āpajjati no antevāsiko, atthāpatti antevāsiko āpajjati no ācariyo, atthāpatti ācariyo ceva āpajjati antevāsiko ca, atthāpatti neva ācariyo āpajjati no antevāsiko.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.12.eng: (1) There are offenses committed by the teacher, but not the pupil. (2) There are offenses committed by the pupil, but not the teacher. (3) There are offenses committed by both the teacher and the pupil. (4) There are offenses committed by neither the teacher nor the pupil.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.12.comm: Sp 5.324: Ācariyacatukkepi eseva nayo, “Also in the tetrad on the teacher, this is the method.”

pli-tv-pvr7:50.13.eng: There is no offense for breaking the rainy-season residence for these four reasons:

pli-tv-pvr7:50.14.pli: saṅgho vā bhinno hoti, saṅghaṃ vā bhinditukāmā honti, jīvitantarāyo vā hoti, brahmacariyantarāyo vā hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.14.eng: there is a schism in the Sangha; there are some who want to cause a schism in the Sangha; there is a threat to life; there is a threat to the monastic life. —

pli-tv-pvr7:50.15.eng: There are four kinds of bad conduct by speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:50.16.pli: musāvādo, pisuṇā vācā, pharusā vācā, samphappalāpo.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.16.eng: lying, divisive speech, harsh speech, and idle speech. —

pli-tv-pvr7:50.17.eng: There are four kinds of good conduct by speech:

pli-tv-pvr7:50.18.pli: saccavācā, apisuṇā vācā, saṇhā vācā, mantā bhāsā.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.18.eng: truthful speech, non-divisive speech, gentle speech, and meaningful speech.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.19.pli: Atthi ādiyanto garukaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati, payojento lahukaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr7:50.19.eng: (1) There are offenses that are serious when taking for oneself, but light when inciting someone else.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.19.comm: Sp 5.324: Ādiyantacatukke pādaṁ vā atirekapādaṁ vā sahatthā ādiyanto garukaṁ āpajjati, ūnakapādaṁ gaṇhāhīti āṇattiyā aññaṁ payojento lahukaṁ āpajjati. Etena nayena sesapadattayaṁ veditabbaṁ, “In the tetrad on taking for oneself, one commits a serious offense when personally taking a pāda coin or more than a pāda, but one commits a light offense when inciting someone else by asking them to take less than a pāda. The remaining three cases are to be understood through this method.”

pli-tv-pvr7:50.20.pli: atthi ādiyanto lahukaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati, payojento garukaṃ;
pli-tv-pvr7:50.20.eng: (2) There are offenses that are light when taking for oneself, but serious when inciting someone else.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.21.pli: atthi ādiyantopi payojentopi garukaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati;
pli-tv-pvr7:50.21.eng: (3) There are offenses that are serious both when taking for oneself and when inciting someone else.

pli-tv-pvr7:50.22.pli: atthi ādiyantopi payojentopi lahukaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:50.22.eng: (4) There are offenses that are light both when taking for oneself and when inciting someone else.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.1.eng: (1) There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not being stood up for.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.1.comm: Sp 5.324: Abhivādanārahacatukke bhikkhunīnaṁ tāva bhattagge navamabhikkhunito paṭṭhāya upajjhāyāpi abhivādanārahā no paccuṭṭhānārahā. Avisesena ca vippakatabhojanassa bhikkhussa yo koci vuḍḍhataro, “In the tetrad on ‘those who deserve being bowed down to’, in the dining hall, as far as the nuns are concerned, starting from the ninth nun, the preceptor deserves being bowed down to, but not being stood up for; and through non-discrimination, whatever monk is more senior and has not finished his meal.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.2.eng: (2) There are people who deserve being stood up for, but not to being bowed down to.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.2.comm: Sp 5.324: Saṭṭhivassassāpi pārivāsikassa samīpagato tadahupasampannopi paccuṭṭhānāraho no abhivādanāraho, “A monk of sixty years seniority who is on probation, when coming close to one ordained on that very day, deserves being stood up for, but not to being bowed down to.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.3.pli: atthi puggalo abhivādanāraho ceva paccuṭṭhānāraho ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.3.eng: (3) There are people who deserve both being bowed down to and being stood up for.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.3.comm: Sp 5.324: Appaṭikkhittesu ṭhānesu vuḍḍho navakassa abhivādanāraho ceva paccuṭṭhānāraho ca, “When there are no prohibiting grounds, then a more senior monk deserves to have a more junior monk bow down to him and stand up for him.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.4.pli: atthi puggalo neva abhivādanāraho no paccuṭṭhānāraho.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.4.eng: (4) There are people who deserve neither being bowed down to nor being stood up for.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.4.comm: Sp 5.324: Navako pana vuḍḍhassa neva abhivādanāraho na paccuṭṭhānāraho, “But a more junior monk does not deserve to have a more senior monk bow down to him and stand up for him.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.5.eng: (1) There are people who deserve a seat, but not being bowed down to.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.5.comm: Sp 5.324: Āsanārahacatukkassa paṭhamapadaṁ purimacatukke dutiyapadena, dutiyapadañca paṭhamapadena atthato sadisaṁ, “The first case in the tetrad on ‘those who deserve a seat’ is parallel in meaning to the second case in the previous tetrad, and the second case is parallel to the first case.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.6.eng: (2) There are people who deserve being bowed down to, but not a seat.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.7.pli: atthi puggalo āsanāraho ceva abhivādanāraho ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.7.eng: (3) There are people who deserve both a seat and being bowed down to.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.8.pli: atthi puggalo neva āsanāraho no abhivādanāraho.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.8.eng: (4) There are people who deserve neither a seat nor being bowed down to.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.9.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits at the right time, not at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.9.comm: Sp 5.324: Kālacatukke pavāretvā bhuñjanto kāle āpajjati no vikāle, “In the tetrad on ‘at the right time’, if one eats after refusing an invitation to eat more, one commits an offense at the right time, not at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.10.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits at the wrong time, not at the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.10.comm: Sp 5.324: Vikālabhojanāpattiṁ vikāle āpajjati no kāle, “The offense of eating at the wrong time is committed at the wrong time not at the right time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.11.pli: atthāpatti kāle ceva āpajjati vikāle ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.11.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits both at the right time and at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.11.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesaṁ kāle ceva āpajjati vikāle ca, “The rest one commits both at the right time and at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.12.pli: atthāpatti neva kāle āpajjati no vikāle.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.12.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits neither at the right time nor at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.12.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ neva kāle no vikāle, “An offense that is not in common between the monks and the nuns is committed neither at the right time, nor at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.13.pli: Atthi paṭiggahitaṃ kāle kappati, no vikāle;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.13.eng: (1) There are things that when received are allowable at the right time, but not at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.13.comm: Sp 5.324: Paṭiggahitacatukke purebhattaṁ paṭiggahitāmisaṁ kāle kappati no vikāle, “In the tetrad on receiving, food received before the meal is allowable at the right time, not at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.14.pli: atthi paṭiggahitaṃ vikāle kappati, no kāle;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.14.eng: (2) There are things that when received are allowable at the wrong time, but not at the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.14.comm: Sp 5.324: Pānakaṁ vikāle kappati, punadivasamhi no kāle, “A drink is allowable at the wrong time, but not at the right time on the next day.” “A drink” refers to the juice drinks that are allowable in the afternoon.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.15.pli: atthi paṭiggahitaṃ kāle ceva kappati vikāle ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.15.eng: (3) There are things that when received are allowable both at the right time and at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.15.comm: Sp 5.324: Sattāhakālikaṁ yāvajīvikaṁ kāle ceva kappati vikāle ca, “Seven-day tonics and lifetime tonics are allowable both at the right time and at the wrong time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.16.pli: atthi paṭiggahitaṃ neva kāle kappati no vikāle.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.16.eng: (4) There are things that when received are allowable neither at the right time nor at the wrong time.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.16.comm: Sp 5.324: Attano attano kālātītaṁ yāvakālikādittayaṁ akappiyamaṁsaṁ uggahitakamappaṭiggahitakañca neva kāle kappati no vikāle, “(1) For each and every person, the triad beginning with ordinary food, when the right time has lapsed; (2) unallowable meat; (3) what has been picked up; and (4) what has not been received—are all allowable neither at the right time nor at the wrong time.” “The triad beginning with ordinary food” refers to ordinary food, post-midday tonics, and seven-day tonics.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.17.pli: Atthāpatti paccantimesu janapadesu āpajjati, no majjhimesu;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.17.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits outside the central Ganges plain, but not within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.17.comm: Sp 5.324: Paccantimacatukke samudde sīmaṁ bandhanto paccantimesu janapadesu āpajjati, no majjhimesu, “In the tetrad on ‘outside the central Ganges plain’, if one creates a monastery zone in the ocean, one commits an offense outside the central Ganges plain, not within it.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.18.pli: atthāpatti majjhimesu janapadesu āpajjati, no paccantimesu;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.18.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits within the central Ganges plain, but not outside it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.18.comm: Sp 5.324: Pañcavaggena gaṇena upasampādento guṇaṅguṇūpāhanaṁ dhuvanahānaṁ cammattharaṇāni ca majjhimesu janapadesu āpajjati no paccantimesu, “Giving the full ordination in a group of five, wearing sandals with multilayered soles, in unrestricted bathing, and having rugs made of skins, one commits an offense within the central Ganges plain, but not outside it.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.19.pli: atthāpatti paccantimesu ceva janapadesu āpajjati majjhimesu ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.19.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits both outside the central Ganges plain and within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.19.comm: Sp 5.324: Imāni cattāri “idha na kappantī”ti vadantopi paccantimesu āpajjati, “idha kappantī”ti vadanto pana majjhimesu āpajjati. Sesāpattiṁ ubhayattha āpajjati, “In saying that these four are not allowable here, one commits an offense outside the central Ganges plain, but in saying that they are allowable here, one commits an offense within the central Ganges plain. The rest one commits in both places.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.20.pli: atthāpatti neva paccantimesu janapadesu āpajjati no majjhimesu.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.20.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits neither outside the central Ganges plain nor within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.20.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ na katthaci āpajjati, “The offenses that are not in common are not committed anywhere.” The point, presumably, is that the offenses of the monks that are not offenses for the nuns are never committed anywhere by the nuns. And the same for the parallel case of offenses of the nuns that are not offenses for the monks.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.21.pli: Atthi paccantimesu janapadesu kappati, no majjhimesu;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.21.eng: (1) There are things that are allowable outside the central Ganges plain, but not within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.21.comm: Sp 5.324: Dutiyacatukke pañcavaggena gaṇena upasampadādi catubbidhampi vatthu paccantimesu janapadesu kappati. “Idaṁ kappatī”ti dīpetumpi tattheva kappati no majjhimesu, “In the second tetrad, the fourfold action that is the basis for an offense, starting with the full ordination in a group of five, is allowable outside the central Ganges plain. Also to proclaim that, ‘This is allowable,’ is allowable just there, not within the central Ganges plain.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.22.pli: atthi majjhimesu janapadesu kappati, no paccantimesu;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.22.eng: (2) There are things that are allowable within the central Ganges plain, but not outside of it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.22.comm: Sp 5.324: “Idaṁ na kappatī”ti dīpetuṁ pana majjhimesu janapadesu kappati no paccantimesu, “But to proclaim, ‘This isn’t allowable,’ is allowable within the central Ganges plain, but not outside of it.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.23.pli: atthi paccantimesu ceva janapadesu kappati majjhimesu ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.23.eng: (3) There are things that are allowable both outside the central Ganges plain and within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.23.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesaṁ “anujānāmi bhikkhave pañca loṇānī”tiādi anuññātakaṁ ubhayattha kappati, “The rest that is allowed, starting with, ‘Monks, I allow five kinds of salt,’ is allowable in both places.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.24.pli: atthi neva paccantimesu janapadesu kappati no majjhimesu.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.24.eng: (4) There are things that are allowable neither outside the central Ganges plain nor within it.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.24.comm: Sp 5.324: Yaṁ pana akappiyanti paṭikkhittaṁ, taṁ ubhayatthāpi na kappati, “But whatever is prohibited as unallowable is unallowable in both places.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.25.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits inside, but not outside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.25.comm: Sp 5.324: Antoādicatukke anupakhajja seyyādiṁ anto āpajjati no bahi, “In the tetrad on inside etc., when encroaching with a sleeping place, etc., one commits an offense inside, but not outside.” “Encroaching with a sleeping place” refers to Bu Pc 16:1.16.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.26.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits outside, but not inside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.26.comm: Sp 5.324: Ajjhokāse saṅghikamañcādīni nikkhipitvā pakkamanto bahi āpajjati no anto, “Putting a bed, etc., belonging to the Sangha outside and then leaving, one commits an offense outside, but not inside.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.27.pli: atthāpatti anto ceva āpajjati bahi ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.27.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits both inside and outside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.27.comm: Sp 5.324: Sesaṁ anto ceva bahi ca, “The rest are committed both inside and outside.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.28.pli: atthāpatti neva anto āpajjati no bahi.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.28.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits neither inside nor outside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.28.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ neva anto na bahi, “Offenses not in common are committed neither inside nor outside.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.29.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits inside the monastery zone, not outside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.29.comm: Sp 5.324: Antosīmādicatukke āgantuko vattaṁ apūrento antosīmāya āpajjati, “In the tetrad on inside the monastery zone etc., not fulfilling the duties of a newly arrived monk, one commits an offense inside the monastery zone.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.30.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits outside the monastery zone, not inside.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.30.comm: Sp 5.324: Gamiyo bahisīmāya … āpajjati, “One departing commits it outside the monastery zone.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.31.pli: atthāpatti antosīmāya ceva āpajjati bahisīmāya ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.31.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits both inside and outside the monastery zone.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.31.comm: Sp 5.324: Musāvādādiṁ antosīmāya ca bahisīmāya ca āpajjati, “In lying, etc., one commits an offense both inside and outside the monastery zone.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.32.pli: atthāpatti neva antosīmāya āpajjati no bahisīmāya.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.32.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits neither inside nor outside the monastery zone.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.32.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ na katthaci, “Offenses not in common are not committed anywhere.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.33.eng: (1) There are offenses that one commits in inhabited areas, not in the wilderness.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.33.comm: Sp 5.324: Gāmacatukke antaragharapaṭisaṁyuttaṁ sekhiyapaññattiṁ gāme āpajjati no araññe, “In the tetrad on inhabited areas, regarding the rules of training connected with inhabited areas, one commits an offense in an inhabited area, not in the wilderness.” For an explanation of the rendering “inhabited area” for gāma, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.34.eng: (2) There are offenses that one commits in the wilderness, not in inhabited areas.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.34.comm: Sp 5.324: Bhikkhunī aruṇaṁ uṭṭhāpayamānā araññe āpajjati no gāme, “A nun who lets the dawn arise commits an offense in the wilderness, not in an inhabited area.” This is presumably a reference to Bi Ss 3:4.14.1, according to which a bhikkhunī cannot spend the night by herself in the wilderness. The offense is committed at dawn.

pli-tv-pvr7:51.35.pli: atthāpatti gāme ceva āpajjati araññe ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:51.35.eng: (3) There are offenses that one commits both in inhabited areas and in the wilderness.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.35.comm: Sp 5.324: Musāvādādiṁ gāme ceva āpajjati araññe ca, “In lying, etc., one commits an offense both in an inhabited area and in the wilderness.”

pli-tv-pvr7:51.36.pli: atthāpatti neva gāme āpajjati no araññe.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.36.eng: (4) There are offenses that one commits neither in inhabited areas nor in the wilderness.
pli-tv-pvr7:51.36.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ na katthaci, “Offenses not in common are not committed anywhere.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.1.eng: There are four kinds of accusing:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.2.eng: pointing out the action that is the basis for an offense, pointing out the offense, refusing to live together, refusing to act respectfully. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.3.eng: There are four kinds of preliminary actions. —
pli-tv-pvr7:52.3.comm: Sp 5.324: “Chandapārisuddhiutukkhānaṁ bhikkhugaṇanā ca ovādo”ti ime pana “cattāro pubbakiccā”ti veditabbā, “Consent and purity, announcing the season, counting the monks, and the instruction—these are to be understood as the four kinds of preliminary actions.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.4.eng: There are four kinds of readiness. —
pli-tv-pvr7:52.4.comm: Sp 5.324: Cattāro pattakallāti uposatho yāvatikā ca bhikkhū kammappattā te āgatā honti, sabhāgāpattiyo na vijjanti, vajjanīyā ca puggalā tasmiṁ na honti, pattakallanti vuccatīti, “The four kinds of readiness: it is the observance day, all the monks who should be present have arrived, there are no shared offenses, and there is no-one there who should not be present—this is called ‘readiness’.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.5.eng: There are four offenses entailing confession concerning “no other”. —
pli-tv-pvr7:52.5.comm: Sp 5.324: Cattāri anaññapācittiyānīti “etadeva paccayaṁ karitvā anaññaṁ pācittiya”nti evaṁ vuttāni anupakhajjaseyyākappanasikkhāpadaṁ “ehāvuso gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā”ti sikkhāpadaṁ, sañcicca kukkuccaupadahanaṁ, upassutitiṭṭhananti imāni cattāri, “The four offenses entailing confession concerning ‘no other’: those spoken like this: ‘Having done it for this reason and no other, there is an offense entailing confession’, that is, the training rule on encroaching with a sleeping place, the training rule on ‘Come to the town or village’, intentionally giving rise to anxiety, and eavesdropping—these four.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.6.eng: There are four kinds of approval from the monks. —
pli-tv-pvr7:52.6.comm: Sp 5.324: Catasso bhikkhusammutiyoti “ekarattampi ce bhikkhu ticīvarena vippavaseyya aññatra bhikkhusammutiyā, aññaṁ navaṁ santhataṁ kārāpeyya aññatra bhikkhusammutiyā, tato ce uttari vippavaseyya aññatra bhikkhusammutiyā, duṭṭhullaṁ āpattiṁ anupasampannassa āroceyya aññatra bhikkhusammutiyā”ti, “The four kinds of approval from the monks: if a monk stays apart from his three robes even for a single day, except with the approval of the monks; if he makes another new blanket, except with the approval of the monks; if he stays apart longer than that, except with the approval of the monks; if he informs a person who is not fully ordained of a grave offense, except with the approval of the monks.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.7.eng: There are four ways of acting that are wrong:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.8.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.8.eng: one is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.9.eng: There are four ways of acting that are not wrong:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.10.pli: na chandāgatiṃ gacchati, na dosāgatiṃ gacchati, na mohāgatiṃ gacchati, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.10.eng: one is not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.11.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgato alajjī bhikkhu saṅghaṃ bhindati—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.11.eng: When a shameless monk has four qualities, he causes a schism in the Sangha:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.12.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchanto, dosāgatiṃ gacchanto, mohāgatiṃ gacchanto, bhayāgatiṃ gacchanto.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.12.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.13.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgato pesalo bhikkhu bhinnaṃ saṅghaṃ samaggaṃ karoti—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.13.eng: When a good monk has four qualities, he unites a divided Sangha:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.14.pli: na chandāgatiṃ gacchanto, na dosāgatiṃ gacchanto, na mohāgatiṃ gacchanto, na bhayāgatiṃ gacchanto.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.14.eng: he is not biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.15.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno vinayo na pucchitabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.15.eng: When a monk has four qualities, he should not be asked about the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.16.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.16.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.17.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā vinayo na pucchitabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.17.eng: When a monk has four qualities, he should not ask about the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.18.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.18.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.19.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno vinayo na vissajjetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.19.eng: When a monk has four qualities, his questions about the Monastic Law should not be replied to:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.20.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.20.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.21.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā vinayo na vissajjetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.21.eng: When a monk has four qualities, he should not reply to questions about the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.22.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.22.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.23.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno anuyogo na dātabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.23.eng: When a monk has four qualities, he should not be allowed to ask questions:
pli-tv-pvr7:52.23.comm: Sp 5.323: Anuyogo na dātabboti “idaṁ kappatī”ti pucchantassa pucchāya okāso na dātabbo, “aññaṁ pucchā”ti vattabbo. Iti so neva pucchitabbo nāssa pucchā sotabbāti attho, “Anuyogo na dātabbo: when he asks, ‘Is this allowable?’ he should be not be given the opportunity to question. They should say, ‘Ask someone else.’ In this way, he should neither be asked nor should his questions be listened to. This is the meaning.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.24.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.24.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.25.pli: Catūhaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā saddhiṃ vinayo na sākacchitabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:52.25.eng: When a monk has four qualities, you should not discuss the Monastic Law with him:

pli-tv-pvr7:52.26.pli: chandāgatiṃ gacchati, dosāgatiṃ gacchati, mohāgatiṃ gacchati, bhayāgatiṃ gacchati.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.26.eng: he is biased by desire, ill will, confusion, or fear. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.27.eng: There are offenses that one commits when sick, not when not sick;
pli-tv-pvr7:52.27.comm: Sp 5.324: Gilānacatukke aññabhesajjena karaṇīyena lolatāya aññaṁ viññāpento gilāno āpajjati, “In the tetrad on sickness, when one needs one kind of medicine, but because of greed asks for another, one commits an offense when sick.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.28.eng: there are offenses that one commits when not sick, not when sick;
pli-tv-pvr7:52.28.comm: Sp 5.324: Abhesajjakaraṇīyena bhesajjaṁ viññāpento agilāno āpajjati, “When one needs something other than medicine, yet asks for medicine, one commits an offense when not sick.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.29.pli: atthāpatti gilāno ceva āpajjati agilāno ca;
pli-tv-pvr7:52.29.eng: there are offenses that one commits both when sick and when not sick;
pli-tv-pvr7:52.29.comm: Sp 5.324: Musāvādādiṁ ubhopi āpajjanti, “When lying, etc., one commits an offense at both times.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.30.pli: atthāpatti neva gilāno āpajjati no agilāno.
pli-tv-pvr7:52.30.eng: there are offenses that one commits neither when sick nor when not sick. —
pli-tv-pvr7:52.30.comm: Sp 5.324: Asādhāraṇaṁ ubhopi nāpajjanti, “Offenses not in common are not committed at either time.”

pli-tv-pvr7:52.31.eng: There are four kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:52.32.eng: There are four kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.

pli-tv-pvr7:53.1.eng: The section on fours is finished.

pli-tv-pvr7:56.1.eng: The monks have, and the nuns have,

pli-tv-pvr7:56.2.eng: And requisite, in the presence of;

pli-tv-pvr7:56.3.eng: Unknowingly, by body, and in the midst of,

pli-tv-pvr7:58.4.eng: Shining, and by a new arrival.

pli-tv-pvr7:59.1.eng: One departing, variety in the action,

pli-tv-pvr7:60.3.eng: And at the right time, and it is allowable,

pli-tv-pvr7:60.4.eng: Outside the central Ganges plain, allowable.

pli-tv-pvr7:61.1.eng: Inside, and inside the monastery zone,

pli-tv-pvr7:61.2.eng: And in an inhabited area, and with accusing;

pli-tv-pvr7:62.1.eng: Wrong acting, and not wrong acting,

pli-tv-pvr7:62.3.eng: And two on should be asked,

pli-tv-pvr7:62.4.eng: And another two on should reply;

pli-tv-pvr7:63.1.comm: At Pvr 4:3.2 these are said to be the offenses entailing expulsion, the offenses entailing suspension, the offenses entailing confession, the offenses entailing acknowledgment, and the offenses of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.2.eng: There are five classes of offenses. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.3.eng: There are five grounds of training. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.3.comm: At Pvr 4:5.2 these are said to be the refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the abstaining from, the non-doing of, the non-performing of, the non-committing of, the non-transgressing the boundary of, the incapability with respect to the five classes of offenses.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.4.eng: There are five kinds of actions with results in the next life. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.4.comm: Vibh 941: Mātā jīvitā voropitā hoti, pitā jīvitā voropito hoti, arahanto jīvitā voropito hoti, duṭṭhena cittena tathāgatassa lohitaṁ uppāditaṁ hoti, saṅgho bhinno hoti – imāni pañca kammāni ānantarikāni, “Killing one’s mother; killing one’s father; killing a perfected one; with a malicious mind, causing the Buddha to bleed; causing a schism in the Sangha—these five actions have results in the next life.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.5.eng: There are five kinds of people with fixed rebirth. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.5.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañcakesu pañca puggalā niyatāti ānantariyānamevetaṁ gahaṇaṁ, “Five kinds of people with fixed rebirth: this is just a reference to having results in the next life.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.6.eng: There are five offenses involving cutting. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.6.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañca chedanakā āpattiyo nāma pamāṇātikkante mañcapīṭhe nisīdanakaṇḍuppaṭicchādivassikasāṭikāsu sugatacīvare ca veditabbā, “The five offenses involving cutting are to be known as: a bed or bench exceeding the right size; a sitting mat exceeding the right size; an itch-covering cloth exceeding the right size; a rainy-season robe exceeding the right size; a standard robe exceeding the right size.” That is, Bu Pc 87:1.11.1 and Bu Pc 89:2.10.1–92.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.7.eng: There are five reasons for committing an offense. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.7.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañcahākārehīti alajjitā, aññāṇatā, kukkuccappakatatā, akappiye kappiyasaññitā, kappiye akappiyasaññitāti imehi pañcahi, “The five reasons: shamelessness, ignorance, an anxious character, perceiving what is allowable as unallowable, perceiving what is unallowable as allowable—these are the five.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.8.eng: There are five kinds of offenses because of lying.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.8.comm: The commentary has no full stop after āpattiyo, but instead after the next word, musāvāda. Since pañca āpattiyo is mentioned as a separate item above, I here follow the commentarial punctuation. Sp 5.325: Pañca āpattiyo musāvādapaccayāti pārājikathullaccayadukkaṭasaṅghādisesapācittiyā, “The five kinds of offenses because of lying: offenses entailing expulsion, serious offenses, offenses of wrong conduct, offenses entailing suspension, and offenses entailing confession.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.9.eng: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is invalid:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.10.pli: sayaṃ vā kammaṃ na karoti, paraṃ vā na ajjhesati, chandaṃ vā pārisuddhiṃ vā na deti, kayiramāne kamme paṭikkosati, kate vā pana kamme adhammadiṭṭhi hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.10.eng: (1) one does not do the legal procedure oneself; (2) one does not request someone else; (3) one does not give one’s consent or declare one’s purity; (4) one objects while the legal procedure is being carried out; or (5) one has the view that the completed legal procedure is illegitimate.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.11.eng: There are five reasons why a legal procedure is valid:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.12.pli: sayaṃ vā kammaṃ karoti, paraṃ vā ajjhesati, chandaṃ vā pārisuddhiṃ vā deti, kayiramāne kamme nappaṭikkosati, kate vā pana kamme dhammadiṭṭhi hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.12.eng: (1) one does the legal procedure oneself; (2) one requests someone else; (3) one gives one’s consent or declares one’s purity; (4) one does not object while the legal procedure is being carried out; or (5) one has the view that the completed legal procedure is legitimate.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.13.eng: There are five things that are allowable for a monk who only eats almsfood:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.14.eng: (1) visiting families before or after a meal invitation, (2) eating in a group, (3) eating a meal before another, (4) non-determination, (5) non-assignment to another.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.14.comm: Sp 5.325: Anadhiṭṭhānanti “gaṇabhojane aññatra samayā”ti vuttaṁ samayaṁ adhiṭṭhahitvā bhojanaṁ adhiṭṭhānaṁ nāma; tathā akaraṇaṁ anadhiṭṭhānaṁ. Avikappanā nāma yā paramparabhojane vikappanā vuttā, tassā akaraṇaṁ, “Non-determination: since it is said, ‘Eating in a group, except on an appropriate occasion’, then, determining the appropriate occasion is called determining a meal. Not doing that is non-determination. Non-assignment to another: the non-doing of what is called transfer in the rule on eating a meal before another.” The former concerns Bu Pc 32:8.15.1, the latter Bu Pc 33:3.15.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.15.eng: When a monk has five qualities, whether he is a bad monk or firm in morality, he is suspected and mistrusted:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.16.pli: pāpabhikkhupi akuppadhammopi vesiyāgocaro vā hoti, vidhavāgocaro vā hoti, thullakumārigocaro vā hoti, paṇḍakagocaro vā hoti, bhikkhunigocaro vā hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.16.eng: he regularly associates with sex workers, widows, single women, paṇḍakas, or nuns. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.16.comm: For a discussion of the word paṇḍaka, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.17.eng: There are five kinds of oil:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.18.eng: sesame oil, mustard oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, and oil from fat. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.19.eng: There are five kinds of fat:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.20.eng: bear fat, fish fat, alligator fat, pig fat, and donkey fat. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.21.eng: There are five kinds of losses:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.22.eng: loss of relatives, loss of property, loss of health, loss of morality, and loss of view. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.23.eng: There are five kinds of successes:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.24.eng: success in relatives, success in property, success in health, success in morality, and success in view.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.25.eng: There are five reasons why the formal support from a preceptor comes to an end:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.26.pli: upajjhāyo pakkanto vā hoti, vibbhanto vā, kālaṅkato vā, pakkhasaṅkanto vā, āṇattiyeva pañcamī.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.26.eng: (1) the preceptor goes away; (2) the preceptor disrobes; (3) the preceptor dies; (4) the preceptor joins another religion or sect; or (5) the preceptor says so.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.26.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “disrobes” for vibbhanto, see vibbhamati in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.27.eng: There are five kinds of people who should not be given the full ordination:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.28.eng: (1) one lacking in age, (2) one lacking in limbs, (3) one who is deficient as object, (4) one who has acted wrongly, (5) one who is incomplete.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.28.comm: Sp 5.322: Vatthuvipanno nāma paṇḍako tiracchānagato ubhatobyañjanako ca. Avasesā theyyasaṁvāsakādayo aṭṭha abhabbapuggalā karaṇadukkaṭakā nāma, “A paṇḍaka, an animal, and a gynandromorph are called deficient as object. The remaining eight incapable persons, starting with the fake monk, are called those who have acted wrongly.” Sp 5.322: Aparipūro nāma aparipuṇṇapattacīvaro, “One who is incomplete: not complete in bowl and robes.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.29.eng: There are five kinds of rags:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.30.eng: (1) those from a charnel ground, (2) those from a shop, (3) those eaten by rats, (4) those eaten by termites, (5) those burned by fire.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.31.eng: There are five other kinds of rags:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.32.eng: (1) those chewed by cattle, (2) those chewed by goats, (3) those left at a stupa, (4) those discarded from a king’s consecration, (5) those taken to and then brought back from a charnel ground.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.32.comm: Sp 5.325: Thūpacīvaranti vammikaṁ parikkhipitvā balikammakataṁ. Ābhisekikanti nahānaṭṭhāne vā rañño abhisekaṭṭhāne vā chaḍḍitacīvaraṁ. Bhatapaṭiyābhatanti susānaṁ netvā puna ānītakaṁ, “Thūpacīvara: having encircled a hill, it is done as an offering. Ābhisekika: a cloth discarded at a bathing place or at the place of a king’s consecration. Bhatapaṭiyābhata: having taken it to a charnel ground, it is brought back again.” Sp-yoj 5.325: Thūpacīvaranti ettha thūpaṁ parikkhipitvā kataṁ cīvaraṁ thūpacīvaranti dassento āha “vammika”ntiādi, “Thūpacīvara: here, having encircled a stupa, the expression thūpacīvaraṁ referring to a finished robe, ‘hill’ is said, etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.33.eng: There are five kinds of removing:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.34.eng: removing by theft, removing by force, removing dependent on conditions, removing by concealing, removing by drawing lots. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.35.eng: There are five notorious gangsters to be found in the world. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.36.eng: There are five things not to be given away. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.37.eng: There are five things not to be distributed. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.38.pli: Pañcāpattiyo kāyato samuṭṭhanti, na vācato na cittato.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.38.eng: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body, not from speech and mind. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.38.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañcāpattiyo kāyato samuṭṭhantīti paṭhamena āpattisamuṭṭhānena pañca āpattiyo āpajjati, “bhikkhu kappiyasaññī saññācikāya kuṭiṁ karotī”ti evaṁ antarapeyyāle vuttāpattiyo, “The five kinds of offenses that originate from the body: through the first origination of offenses, one commits five offenses. These are the offenses spoken of in the internal repetition in this way: ‘When a monk, perceiving it as allowable and by means of begging, builds a hut.’” The internal repetition is at Pvr 4.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.39.pli: Pañcāpattiyo kāyato ca vācato ca samuṭṭhanti, na cittato.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.39.eng: There are five kinds of offenses that originate from body and speech, not from mind. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.39.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañca āpattiyo kāyato ca vācato cāti tatiyena āpattisamuṭṭhānena pañca āpattiyo āpajjati, “bhikkhu kappiyasaññī saṁvidahitvā kuṭiṁ karotī”ti evaṁ tattheva vuttā āpattiyo, “The five kinds of offenses that originate from the body and speech: through the third origination of offenses, one commits five offenses. These are the offenses spoken of just there in this way: ‘When a monk, perceiving it as allowable and having appointed someone, builds a hut.’” Again, this refers to the internal repetition.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.40.eng: There are five kinds of offenses that are confessable. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.40.comm: Sp 5.325: Desanāgāminiyoti ṭhapetvā pārājikañca saṅghādisesañca avasesā, “Confessable: apart from the offenses entailing expulsion and the offenses entailing suspension, the rest.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.41.eng: There are five kinds of sangha. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.42.eng: There are five ways of reciting the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.43.eng: Outside the central Ganges plain, the full ordination is to be given by a group of five, including one expert on the Monastic Law. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.44.eng: There are five benefits of performing the robe-making ceremony. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.45.eng: There are five kinds of legal procedures. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.45.comm: Sp 5.325: Pañca kammānīti tajjanīyaniyassapabbājanīyapaṭisāraṇīyāni cattāri ukkhepanīyañca tividhampi ekanti pañca, “The five kinds of legal procedures: condemnation, demotion, banishment, and reconciliation are four, and the threefold ejection is one, making it five.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.46.eng: There are five ‘for the third time’ offenses. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.46.comm: Sp 5.325: Yāvatatiyake pañcāti ukkhittānuvattikāya bhikkhuniyā yāvatatiyaṁ samanubhāsanāya appaṭinissajjantiyā pārājikaṁ thullaccayaṁ dukkaṭanti tisso, bhedakānuvattakādisamanubhāsanāsu saṅghādiseso, pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā appaṭinissagge pācittiyaṁ, “The five ‘for the third time’: when a nun takes sides with one who has been ejected and does not stop when pressed for the third time, there are three offenses: the offense entailing expulsion, the serious offense, and the offense of wrong conduct. When pressing one who is supporting a schism, etc., there is an offense entailing suspension. For not giving up a bad view, there is an offense entailing confession.”

pli-tv-pvr7:63.47.eng: When five factors are fulfilled, there is an offense entailing expulsion for one who steals. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.48.eng: When five factors are fulfilled, there is a serious offense for one who steals. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.49.eng: When five factors are fulfilled, there is an offense of wrong conduct for one who steals. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.50.eng: There are five unallowable things that should not be used:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.51.pli: adinnañca hoti, aviditañca hoti, akappiyañca hoti, appaṭiggahitañca hoti, akatātirittañca hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.51.eng: what has not been given, what is not known about, what is not allowable, what has not been received, what has not been made left over. —
pli-tv-pvr7:63.51.comm: Sp 5.325: Aviditanti paṭiggaṇhāmīti cetanāya abhāvena aviditaṁ, “Avidita: not known about because of the absence of the volition ‘I receive’.” The point may simply be that one does not know whether a certain food has been received or not.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.52.eng: There are five allowable things that may be used:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.53.pli: dinnañca hoti, viditañca hoti, kappiyañca hoti, paṭiggahitañca hoti, katātirittañca hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.53.eng: what has been given, what is known about, what is allowable, what has been received, what has been made left over. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.54.eng: There are five gifts without merit that are considered meritorious in the world:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.55.eng: alcohol, entertainment, a woman, a bull, and a picture. —

pli-tv-pvr7:63.56.eng: There are five things that are hard to remove:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.57.pli: uppanno rāgo duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno doso duppaṭivinodayo, uppanno moho duppaṭivinodayo, uppannaṃ paṭibhānaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ, uppannaṃ gamiyacittaṃ duppaṭivinodayaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.57.eng: desire, ill will, confusion, feeling inspired to speak, and the thought of departing.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.58.eng: There are five benefits of sweeping:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.59.pli: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, pāsādikasaṃvattanikakammaṃ upacinati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.59.eng: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one accumulates actions that lead to being inspiring, (5) at the break-up of the body after death one is reborn in heaven.

pli-tv-pvr7:63.60.eng: There are five other benefits of sweeping:

pli-tv-pvr7:63.61.pli: sakacittaṃ pasīdati, paracittaṃ pasīdati, devatā attamanā honti, satthusāsanaṃ kataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:63.61.eng: (1) one’s own mind becomes serene, (2) the minds of others become serene, (3) the gods are pleased, (4) one carries out the Teacher’s instruction, (5) later generations follow one’s example.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.1.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.2.pli: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggahetvā adhammena kāreti appaṭiññāya.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.2.eng: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.2.comm: Sp 5.325: Attano bhāsapariyantaṁ na uggaṇhātīti “imasmiṁ vatthusmiṁ ettakaṁ suttaṁ upalabbhati, ettako vinicchayo, ettakaṁ suttañca vinicchayañca vakkhāmī”ti evaṁ attano bhāsapariyantaṁ na uggaṇhāti. “Ayaṁ codakassa purimakathā, ayaṁ pacchimakathā, ayaṁ cuditakassa purimakathā, ayaṁ pacchimakathā, ettakaṁ gayhūpagaṁ, ettakaṁ na gayhūpaga”nti evaṁ anuggaṇhanto pana parassa bhāsapariyantaṁ na uggaṇhāti nāma, “Attano bhāsapariyantaṁ na uggaṇhāti: ‘In regard to this action that is a basis for an offense, this is the rule and this is its application. I will speak about the rule and its application.’ He does not grasp, in such a way, what is proper for himself to say. ‘This was said first by the accuser, this was said last. This was said first by the accused, this was said last. This is fit to be taken up, this is not.’ If he does not grasp, in such a way, it is called, ‘He does not grasp what is proper for others to say’.” In the Suttas, pariyanta, when used in combination with speech, often refers to conciseness of speech, e.g. in the gradual training at MN 27. Here the context requires a different meaning.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.3.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.3.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.4.pli: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ uggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ uggahetvā dhammena kāreti paṭiññāya.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.4.eng: (1) he grasps what is proper for himself to say; (2) he grasps what is proper for others to say; (3-5) grasping both, he makes them act legitimately, in accordance with their admission.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.5.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.5.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.6.pli: āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.6.eng: (1) he does not know the offenses; (2) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (3) he does not know the origins of the offenses; (4) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.7.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.7.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.8.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.8.eng: (1) he knows the offenses; (2) he knows the roots of the offenses; (3) he knows the origins of the offenses; (4) he knows the ending of the offenses; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.9.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.9.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.10.pli: adhikaraṇaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇassa mūlaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇasamudayaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.10.eng: (1) he does not know the legal issues; (2) he does not know the roots of the legal issues; (3) he does not know the origins of the legal issues; (4) he does not know the ending of the legal issues; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.11.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.11.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.12.pli: adhikaraṇaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇassa mūlaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇasamudayaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.12.eng: (1) he knows the legal issues; (2) he knows the roots of the legal issues; (3) he knows the origins of the legal issues; (4) he knows the ending of the legal issues; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of the legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.13.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.13.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.14.pli: vatthuṃ na jānāti, nidānaṃ na jānāti, paññattiṃ na jānāti, anupaññattiṃ na jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ na jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.14.eng: (1) he does not know the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he does not know the origin stories; (3) he does not know the rules; (4) he does not know the additions to the rules; (5) he does not know the sequence of statements.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.14.comm: Sp 5.359: Anusandhivacanapathaṁ na jānātīti kathānusandhivacanaṁ vinicchayānusandhivacanañca na jānāti, “‘He does not know the sequence of statements’: he does not know the sequence of statements and the sequence of decisions.”

pli-tv-pvr7:64.15.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.15.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.16.pli: vatthuṃ jānāti, nidānaṃ jānāti, paññattiṃ jānāti, anupaññattiṃ jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.16.eng: (1) he knows the actions that are the bases for offenses; (2) he knows the origin stories; (3) he knows the rules; (4) he knows the additions to the rules; (5) he knows the sequence of statements.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.17.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.17.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.18.pli: ñattiṃ na jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ na jānāti, na pubbakusalo hoti, na aparakusalo hoti, akālaññū ca hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.18.eng: (1) he does not know the motion; (2) he does not know how the motion is done; (3) he is not skilled in what comes first; (4) he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he does not know the right time.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.18.comm: Sp 5.325: Na pubbakusalo hoti na aparakusaloti pubbe kathetabbañca pacchā kathetabbañca na jānāti, ñatti nāma pubbe ṭhapetabbā, pacchā na ṭhapetabbātipi na jānāti, “He is not skilled in what comes first; he is not skilled in what comes afterwards: he does not know what should be said first and what should be said afterwards. He does not know that the motion should be put forward first, not afterwards.”

pli-tv-pvr7:64.19.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.19.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.20.pli: ñattiṃ jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ jānāti, pubbakusalo hoti, aparakusalo hoti, kālaññū ca hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.20.eng: (1) he knows the motion; (2) he knows how the motion is done; (3) he is skilled in what comes first; (4) he is skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he knows the right time.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.21.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.21.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.22.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa na suggahitā hoti na sumanasikatā na sūpadhāritā.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.22.eng: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.23.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.23.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.24.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānati, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.24.eng: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.25.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.25.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.26.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni na vitthārena svāgatāni honti na suvibhattāni na suppavattīni na suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.26.eng: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not properly learned either Monastic Codes in detail, and he has not analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, or investigated them well, either in terms of the rules or their detailed exposition.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.27.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.27.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.28.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.28.eng: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, and has analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition.

pli-tv-pvr7:64.29.pli: Aparehipi pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.29.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has five other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.30.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca na vinicchayakusalo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.30.eng: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he is not skilled in deciding legal issues.
