pli-tv-pvr7:64.31.pli: Pañcahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:64.31.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has five qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:64.32.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca vinicchayakusalo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:64.32.eng: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he is skilled in deciding legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr7:65.1.eng: There are five kinds of wilderness dwellers:

pli-tv-pvr7:65.2.pli: mandattā momūhattā āraññiko hoti, pāpiccho icchāpakato āraññiko hoti, ummādā cittakkhepā āraññiko hoti, “vaṇṇitaṃ buddhehi buddhasāvakehī”ti āraññiko hoti, api ca appicchaññeva nissāya santuṭṭhiññeva nissāya sallekhaññeva nissāya pavivekaññeva nissāya idamatthitaññeva nissāya āraññiko hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.2.eng: one who is a wilderness dweller (1) because of stupidity and folly; (2) because one is overcome by bad desires; (3) because of insanity and derangement; (4) because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples; or (5) because of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and not needing anything else.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.2.comm: Sp 5.325: Taṁ idamatthitaṁyeva nissāya na aññaṁ kiñci lokāmisanti attho, “They depend on ‘not needing anything else’, not on any other material things. This is the meaning.”

pli-tv-pvr7:65.3.eng: There are five kinds of people who only eat almsfood …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.4.eng: There are five kinds of rag-robe wearers …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.5.eng: There are five kinds of people who live at the foot of a tree …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.6.eng: There are five kinds of people who live in charnel grounds …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.7.eng: There are five kinds of people who live out in the open …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.7.comm: For an explanation of the rendering “out in the open” for abbhokāsa, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:65.8.eng: There are five kinds of people who only have three robes …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.9.eng: There are five kinds of people who go on continuous almsround …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.10.eng: There are five kinds of people who never lie down …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.11.eng: There are five kinds of people who accept any kind of resting place …
pli-tv-pvr7:65.11.comm: Nidd-a.I.17: Yadeva santhataṁ yathāsanthataṁ, idaṁ tuyhaṁ pāpuṇātīti evaṁ paṭhamaṁ uddiṭṭhasenāsanassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ, “Yathāsanthata: whatever is a mat. ‘This is for you’: in this way this is a description of the resting place one is designated first.”

pli-tv-pvr7:65.12.eng: There are five kinds of people who eat in one sitting per day …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.13.eng: There are five kinds of people who refuse to accept food offered after the meal has begun …

pli-tv-pvr7:65.14.eng: There are five kinds of people who eat only from the almsbowl:

pli-tv-pvr7:65.15.pli: mandattā momūhattā pattapiṇḍiko hoti, pāpiccho icchāpakato pattapiṇḍiko hoti, ummādā cittakkhepā pattapiṇḍiko hoti, “vaṇṇitaṃ buddhehi buddhasāvakehī”ti pattapiṇḍiko hoti, api ca appicchaññeva nissāya santuṭṭhiññeva nissāya sallekhaññeva nissāya pavivekaññeva nissāya idamatthitaññeva nissāya pattapiṇḍiko hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:65.15.eng: one who eats only from the almsbowl (1) because of stupidity and folly; (2) because one is overcome by bad desires; (3) because of insanity and derangement; (4) because it is praised by the Buddhas and their disciples; or (5) because of fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and not needing anything else.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.1.eng: There are five dangers in being uninspiring:
pli-tv-pvr7:67.1.comm: Sp 5.325: Apāsādikanti kāyaduccaritādi akusalakammaṁ vuccati, “Unwholesome actions of misconduct by body, etc., are called ‘being uninspiring’.”

pli-tv-pvr7:67.2.pli: attāpi attānaṃ upavadati, anuviccapi viññū garahanti, pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati, sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.2.eng: (1) you criticize yourself; (2) after investigating, wise people condemn you; (3) you get a bad reputation; (4) you die confused; (5) after death, you are reborn in a lower realm.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.3.eng: There are five benefits in being inspiring:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.4.pli: attāpi attānaṃ na upavadati, anuviccapi viññū pasaṃsanti, kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati, asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.4.eng: (1) you do not criticize yourself; (2) after investigating, wise people praise you; (3) you get a good reputation; (4) you die unconfused; (5) after death, you are reborn in heaven.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.5.eng: There are five other dangers in being uninspiring:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.6.pli: appasannā na pasīdanti, pasannānaṃ ekaccānaṃ aññathattaṃ hoti, satthusāsanaṃ akataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ nāpajjati, cittamassa na pasīdati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.6.eng: (1) you do not give rise to confidence in those without it; (2) you cause some to lose their confidence; (3) you don’t carry out the Teacher’s instructions; (4) later generations follow your example; (5) your mind doesn’t become serene.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.6.comm: I read āpajjati with SRT, as against nāpajjati in MS.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.7.eng: And there are five benefits in being inspiring:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.8.pli: appasannā pasīdanti, pasannānaṃ bhiyyobhāvāya hoti, satthusāsanaṃ kataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, cittamassa pasīdati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.8.eng: (1) you give rise to confidence in those without it; (2) you increase the confidence of those who have it; (3) you carry out the Teacher’s instructions; (4) later generations follow your example; (5) your mind becomes serene.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.9.eng: There are five dangers of associating with families:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.10.pli: anāmantacāre āpajjati, raho nisajjāya āpajjati, paṭicchanne āsane āpajjati, mātugāmassa uttarichappañcavācāhi dhammaṃ desento āpajjati, kāmasaṅkappabahulo ca viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.10.eng: (1) one commits the offense of visiting families before or after a meal invitation; (2) one commits the offense of sitting down in private; (3) one commits the offense of sitting down on a concealed seat; (4) one commits the offense of teaching more than five or six sentences to a woman; (5) one has a lot of worldly thoughts.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.10.comm: The first four of these refer respectively to: Bu Pc 46:5.6.1/Bi Pc 127; Bu Pc 45:1.14.1/Bi Pc 126; Bu Pc 44:1.14.1/Bi Pc 125; and Bu Pc 7:3.11.1/Bi Pc 103.

pli-tv-pvr7:67.11.eng: There are five dangers for a monk who associates with families:

pli-tv-pvr7:67.12.pli: ativelaṃ kulesu saṃsaṭṭhassa viharato mātugāmassa abhiṇhadassanaṃ, dassane sati saṃsaggo, saṃsagge sati vissāso, vissāse sati otāro, otiṇṇacittassetaṃ bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṃ carissati aññataraṃ vā saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjissati sikkhaṃ vā paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissati.
pli-tv-pvr7:67.12.eng: (1) when he associates too much with families, he often sees women; (2) because of seeing them, he associates with them; (3) because of associating with them, there is intimacy; (4) because of intimacy, there is lust; (5) because his mind is overcome by lust, it is to be expected that he will be dissatisfied with the spiritual life, that he will commit a certain defiled offense, or that he will renounce the training and return to the lower life.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.1.eng: There are five kinds of propagation:

pli-tv-pvr7:68.2.pli: mūlabījaṃ, khandhabījaṃ, phaḷubījaṃ, aggabījaṃ, bījabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.2.eng: (1) propagation from roots, (2) propagation from stems, (3) propagation from joints, (4) propagation from cuttings, (5) propagation from regular seeds as the fifth.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.3.eng: When fruit is allowable for monastics for any of five reasons, it may be eaten:

pli-tv-pvr7:68.4.pli: aggiparijitaṃ, satthaparijitaṃ, nakhaparijitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbattabījaññeva pañcamaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.4.eng: (1) it has been damaged by fire, (2) it has been damaged by a knife, (3) it has been damaged by a fingernail, (4) it’s seedless, (5) the seeds have been removed.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.5.eng: There are five kinds of purification:

pli-tv-pvr7:68.6.pli: nidānaṃ uddisitvā avasesaṃ sutena sāvetabbaṃ, ayaṃ paṭhamā visuddhi;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.6.eng: (1) After reciting the introduction, the rest is announced as if heard.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.7.pli: nidānaṃ uddisitvā cattāri pārājikāni uddisitvā avasesaṃ sutena sāvetabbaṃ, ayaṃ dutiyā visuddhi;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.7.eng: (2) After reciting the introduction and the four rules entailing expulsion, the rest is announced as if heard.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.8.pli: nidānaṃ uddisitvā cattāri pārājikāni uddisitvā terasa saṅghādisese uddisitvā avasesaṃ sutena sāvetabbaṃ, ayaṃ tatiyā visuddhi;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.8.eng: (3) After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, and the thirteen rules entailing suspension, the rest is announced as if heard.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.9.pli: nidānaṃ uddisitvā cattāri pārājikāni uddisitvā terasa saṅghādisese uddisitvā dve aniyate uddisitvā avasesaṃ sutena sāvetabbaṃ, ayaṃ catutthā visuddhi;
pli-tv-pvr7:68.9.eng: (4) After reciting the introduction, the four rules entailing expulsion, the thirteen rules entailing suspension, and the two undetermined rules, the rest is announced as if heard.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.11.eng: There are five other kinds of purification:

pli-tv-pvr7:68.12.pli: suttuddeso, pārisuddhiuposatho, adhiṭṭhānuposatho, pavāraṇā, sāmaggīuposathoyeva pañcamo.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.12.eng: (1) the observance-day ceremony which consists of reciting the Monastic Code, (2) the observance-day ceremony which consists of declaring purity, (3) the observance-day ceremony which consists of a determination, (4) the invitation ceremony, (5) the observance-day ceremony for the sake of unity as the fifth.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.13.eng: There are five benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:68.14.pli: attano sīlakkhandho sugutto hoti surakkhito, kukkuccapakatānaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ hoti, visārado saṅghamajjhe voharati, paccatthike sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggaṇhāti, saddhammaṭṭhitiyā paṭipanno hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:68.14.eng: (1) your own morality is well guarded; (2) you are a refuge for those who are habitually anxious; (3) you speak with confidence in the midst of the Sangha; (4) you can legitimately and properly refute an opponent; (5) you are practicing for the longevity of the true Teaching.

pli-tv-pvr7:68.15.eng: There are five kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:68.16.eng: There are five kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.”

pli-tv-pvr7:71.2.eng: Training, and with the next life;

pli-tv-pvr7:72.4.eng: Comes to an end, and with people.

pli-tv-pvr7:73.2.eng: Theft, and one called a gangster;

pli-tv-pvr7:73.3.eng: Not to be given away, not to be shared out,

pli-tv-pvr7:73.4.eng: From body, from body and speech.

pli-tv-pvr7:74.2.eng: Outside, and with the robe-making ceremony;

pli-tv-pvr7:74.3.eng: Legal procedures, for the third time,

pli-tv-pvr7:74.4.eng: An offense entailing expulsion, a serious offense, an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-pvr7:76.1.eng: Legal issue, action that is the basis for an offense, motion,

pli-tv-pvr7:76.4.eng: You should understand dark and bright.

pli-tv-pvr7:77.2.eng: Rag-robe, tree, people who live in charnel grounds;

pli-tv-pvr7:77.3.eng: Out in the open, and robe,

pli-tv-pvr7:77.4.eng: Continuous, one who never lies down.

pli-tv-pvr7:78.2.eng: And one who eats only from the bowl;

pli-tv-pvr7:79.1.eng: These verses on dark and bright,

pli-tv-pvr7:79.2.eng: They are the same for the nuns;

pli-tv-pvr7:80.5.eng: And so legitimate is spoken of,

pli-tv-pvr7:81.2.eng: There are six kinds of respect. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.3.eng: There are six grounds of training. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.4.comm: Sp 5.326: Cha sāmīciyoti “so ca bhikkhu anabbhito, te ca bhikkhū gārayhā, ayaṁ tattha sāmīci”, “yuñjantāyasmanto sakaṁ, mā vo sakaṁ vinassāti ayaṁ tattha sāmīci”, “ayaṁ te bhikkhu patto yāva bhedanāya dhāretabboti ayaṁ tattha sāmīci”, “tato nīharitvā bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ saṁvibhajitabbaṁ, ayaṁ tattha sāmīci”, “aññātabbaṁ paripucchitabbaṁ paripañhitabbaṁ, ayaṁ tattha sāmīci”, “yassa bhavissati so harissatīti ayaṁ tattha sāmīcī”ti imā bhikkhupātimokkheyeva cha sāmīciyo, “The six proper ways: ‘That monk is not rehabilitated and those monks are at fault. This is the proper procedure;’ ‘“Please recover what’s yours, or it might perish.” This is the proper procedure;’ ‘“Monk, this bowl is yours. Keep it until it breaks.” This is the proper procedure;’ ‘He should take it away and share it with the monks. This is the proper procedure;’ ‘He should understand, should question, should enquire. This is the proper procedure;’ ‘“Whoever owns it will come and get it.” This is the proper procedure.’ These are the six proper ways in the Monastic Code for the monks.”

pli-tv-pvr7:81.5.eng: There are six originations of offenses. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.6.eng: There are six offenses involving cutting. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.6.comm: Sp 5.326: Cha chedanakāti pañcake vuttā pañca bhikkhunīnaṁ udakasāṭikāya saddhiṁ cha, “The six involving cutting: the five mentioned in the fives together with the bathing robe for nuns, making it six.”

pli-tv-pvr7:81.7.eng: There are six ways of committing an offense. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.7.comm: Sp 5.326: Chahākārehīti alajjitā aññāṇatā kukkuccapakatatā akappiye kappiyasaññitā kappiye akappiyasaññitā satisammosāti, “The six ways: shamelessness, ignorance, an anxious character, perceiving what is allowable as unallowable, perceiving what is unallowable as allowable, and absentmindedness.”

pli-tv-pvr7:81.8.eng: There are six benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.8.comm: Sp 5.326: Cha ānisaṁsā vinayadhareti pañcake vuttā pañca tassādheyyo uposathoti iminā saddhiṁ cha, “The six benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law: the five mentioned in the fives together with the observance-day ceremony being entrusted to them, making it six.”

pli-tv-pvr7:81.9.eng: There are six rules about ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.9.comm: Sp 5.326: Cha paramānīti “dasāhaparamaṁ atirekacīvaraṁ dhāretabbaṁ, māsaparamaṁ tena bhikkhunā taṁ cīvaraṁ nikkhipitabbaṁ, santaruttaraparamaṁ tena bhikkhunā tato cīvaraṁ sāditabbaṁ, chakkhattuparamaṁ tuṇhībhūtena uddissa ṭhātabbaṁ, navaṁ pana bhikkhunā santhataṁ kārāpetvā chabbassāni dhāretabbaṁ chabbassaparamatā dhāretabbaṁ, tiyojanaparamaṁ sahatthā dhāretabbāni, dasāhaparamaṁ atirekapatto dhāretabbo, sattāhaparamaṁ sannidhikārakaṁ paribhuñjitabbāni, chārattaparamaṁ tena bhikkhunā tena cīvarena vippavasitabbaṁ, catukkaṁsaparamaṁ, aḍḍhateyyakaṁsaparamaṁ, dvaṅgulapabbaparamaṁ ādātabbaṁ, aṭṭhaṅgulaparamaṁ mañcapaṭipādakaṁ, aṭṭhaṅgulaparamaṁ dantakaṭṭha”nti imāni cuddasa paramāni. Tattha paṭhamāni cha ekaṁ chakkaṁ, “The six rules on ‘at the most’: ‘Should keep an extra robe for ten days at the most;’ ‘He should keep it at most one month;’ ‘He should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe;’ ‘Should stand in silence for it at most six times;’ ‘If a monk has had a new blanket made, he should keep it for six years. He should keep it for six years at a minimum;’ ‘May carry it himself for at most 40 kilometers;’ ‘Should keep an extra almsbowl for ten days at the most;’ ‘Should be used from storage for at most seven days;’ ‘He should stay apart from that robe for six days at the most;’ ‘It is to be worth at most four kaṁsa coins;’ ‘It is to be worth at most two-and-a-half kaṁsa coins;’ ‘May insert two finger joints at the most;’ ‘Bed supports that are at the most eight standard fingerbreadths long;’ ‘Tooth cleaners that are at most thirteen centimeters long.’ These are the fourteen rules on ‘at the most’. There, the first six are one set of sixes.” These quotes refer respectively to Bu NP 1:2.17.1, Bu NP 3:1.3.13.1, Bu NP 7:1.31.1, Bu NP 10:1.3.1, Bu NP 14:2.38.1, Bu NP 16:1.23.1, Bu NP 21:2.17.1, Bu NP 23:1.3.32.1, Bu NP 29:1.2.16.1, Bi NP 11:1.21.1, Bi NP 12:1.21.1, Bi Pc 5:1.2.12.1, Kd 16:2.5.16, and Kd 15:31.2.5.

pli-tv-pvr7:81.10.eng: One may be stay apart from one’s three robes for six days. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.11.eng: There are six kinds of robe-cloth. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.12.eng: There are six kinds of dye. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.13.pli: Cha āpattiyo kāyato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti na vācato.
pli-tv-pvr7:81.13.eng: There are six kinds of offenses that originate from body and mind, not from speech. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.14.pli: Cha āpattiyo vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti na kāyato.
pli-tv-pvr7:81.14.eng: There are six kinds of offenses that originate from speech and mind, not from body. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.15.pli: Cha āpattiyo kāyato ca vācato ca cittato ca samuṭṭhanti.
pli-tv-pvr7:81.15.eng: There are six kinds of offenses that originate from body, speech, and mind. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.16.eng: There are six kinds of legal procedures. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.16.comm: Sp 5.326: Cha kammānīti tajjanīya-niyassa-pabbājanīya-paṭisāraṇīyāni cattāri, āpattiyā adassane ca appaṭikamme ca vuttadvayampi ekaṁ, pāpikāya diṭṭhiyā appaṭinissagge ekanti cha, “The six kinds of legal procedures: condemnation, demotion, banishment, and reconciliation are four, the mentioned pair of not recognizing and not making amends for an offense is one, and not letting go of a bad view is one, making it six.”

pli-tv-pvr7:81.17.eng: There are six roots of disputes. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.18.eng: There are six roots of accusations. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.19.eng: There are six aspects of friendliness. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.19.comm: There is no apparent reason why this set of sixes in included here. Apart from the Parivāra, it is not encountered elsewhere in the Vinaya Piṭaka, but see MN 48:6.2.

pli-tv-pvr7:81.22.eng: There are six reasons why the formal support from a teacher comes to an end. —

pli-tv-pvr7:81.23.eng: There are six additions to the rule on bathing. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.23.comm: Sp 5.326: Nahāneti orenaḍḍhamāsaṁ nahāne, “On bathing: on bathing at intervals of less than a half-month.” This refers to Bu Pc 57:6.7.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:81.24.eng: One takes an unfinished robe and leaves the monastery. —
pli-tv-pvr7:81.24.comm: Sp 5.326: Vippakatacīvarādichakkadvayaṁ kathinakkhandhake niddiṭṭhaṁ, “The pair of sixes on an unfinished robe, etc., are specified in The Chapter on the Robe-making Ceremony.” See Kd 7:4.1.0. This segment and the next each constitute a separate set of sixes.

pli-tv-pvr7:81.25.eng: One leaves the monastery with an unfinished robe.

pli-tv-pvr7:82.1.pli: Chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:82.1.eng: When a monk has six qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:82.2.pli: asekkhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena paññakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, asekkhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:82.2.eng: he has (1) the virtue, (2) stillness, (3) wisdom, (4) freedom, and (5) the knowledge and vision of freedom of one who is fully trained, and (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:83.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:83.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:83.2.pli: attanā asekkhena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe sīlakkhandhe samādapetā;
pli-tv-pvr7:83.2.eng: (1) he has the virtue of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

pli-tv-pvr7:83.3.pli: attanā asekkhena samādhikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe samādhikkhandhe samādapetā;
pli-tv-pvr7:83.3.eng: (2) he has the stillness of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

pli-tv-pvr7:83.4.pli: attanā asekkhena paññakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe paññakkhandhe samādapetā;
pli-tv-pvr7:83.4.eng: (3) he has the wisdom of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

pli-tv-pvr7:83.5.pli: attanā asekkhena vimuttikkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe vimuttikkhandhe samādapetā;
pli-tv-pvr7:83.5.eng: (4) he has the freedom of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

pli-tv-pvr7:83.6.pli: attanā asekkhena vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhena samannāgato hoti, paraṃ asekkhe vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandhe samādapetā;
pli-tv-pvr7:83.6.eng: (5) he has the knowledge and vision of freedom of one who is fully trained himself and encourages others in it;

pli-tv-pvr7:83.7.eng: (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:84.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:84.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:84.2.pli: saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:84.2.eng: he has (1) faith, (2) conscience, (3) moral prudence, (4) energy, (5) mindfulness, and (6) ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:85.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:85.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:85.2.pli: na adhisīle sīlavipanno hoti, na ajjhācāre ācāravipanno hoti, na atidiṭṭhiyā diṭṭhivipanno hoti, bahussuto hoti, paññavā hoti, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:85.2.eng: (1) he has not failed in the higher morality; (2) he has not failed in conduct; (3) he has not failed in view; (4) he is learned; (5) he is wise; (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:86.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:86.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:86.2.pli: paṭibalo hoti antevāsiṃ vā saddhivihāriṃ vā gilānaṃ upaṭṭhātuṃ vā upaṭṭhāpetuṃ vā, anabhirataṃ vūpakāsetuṃ vā vūpakāsāpetuṃ vā, uppannaṃ kukkuccaṃ dhammato vinodetuṃ, āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattivuṭṭhānaṃ jānāti, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:86.2.eng: he is capable of three things in regard to a student: (1) to nurse him or have him nursed when he is sick; (2) to send him away or have him sent away when he is discontent with the spiritual life; (3) to use the Teaching to dispel anxiety. And (4) he knows the offenses; (5) he knows how offenses are cleared; and (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:87.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:87.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:87.2.pli: paṭibalo hoti antevāsiṃ vā saddhivihāriṃ vā ābhisamācārikāya sikkhāya sikkhāpetuṃ, ādibrahmacāriyakāya sikkhāya vinetuṃ, abhidhamme vinetuṃ, abhivinaye vinetuṃ, uppannaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ dhammato vivecetuṃ, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:87.2.eng: he is capable of five things in regard to a student: (1) to train him in good conduct; (2) to train him in the basics of the spiritual life; (3) to train him in the Teaching; (4) to train him in the Monastic Law; and (5) to use the Teaching to make him give up wrong views. And (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:88.1.pli: Aparehipi chahaṅgehi samannāgatena bhikkhunā upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo—
pli-tv-pvr7:88.1.eng: When a monk has six other qualities, he may give the full ordination, give formal support, and have a novice monk attend on him:

pli-tv-pvr7:88.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso, dasavasso vā hoti atirekadasavasso vā.
pli-tv-pvr7:88.2.eng: (1) he knows the offenses; (2) he knows the non-offenses; (3) he knows the light offenses; (4) he knows the heavy offenses; (5) he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, and he has analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition; (6) he has ten or more years of seniority.

pli-tv-pvr7:89.1.eng: There are six kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:89.2.eng: There are six kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.”

pli-tv-pvr7:90.1.eng: The section on sixes is finished.

pli-tv-pvr7:94.1.eng: And from body, speech and mind,

pli-tv-pvr7:96.2.eng: There are seven classes of offenses. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.3.eng: There are seven grounds of training. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.4.comm: Sp 5.327: Satta sāmīciyoti pubbe vuttesu chasu “sā ca bhikkhunī anabbhitā, tā ca bhikkhuniyo gārayhā, ayaṁ tattha sāmīcī”ti imaṁ pakkhipitvā satta veditabbā , “The seven proper ways: the seven are to be understood as the six previously spoken of and adding this: ‘That nun is not rehabilitated and those nuns are at fault. This is proper procedure.’”

pli-tv-pvr7:96.5.eng: There are seven illegitimate ways of acting according to what has been admitted. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.5.comm: Sp 5.327: Satta adhammikā paṭiññātakaraṇāti “bhikkhu pārājikaṁ ajjhāpanno hoti, pārājikena codiyamāno ‘saṅghādisesaṁ ajjhāpannomhī’ti paṭijānāti, taṁ saṅgho saṅghādisesena kāreti, adhammikaṁ paṭiññātakaraṇa”nti evaṁ samathakkhandhake niddiṭṭhā, “The seven illegitimate ways of acting according to what has been admitted: ‘A monk has committed an offense entailing expulsion. When he is accused of having committed such an offense, he admits to committing an offense entailing suspension. The Sangha deals with him for an offense entailing suspension. That acting according to what has been admitted is illegitimate.’ In this way, it is specified in The Chapter on the Settling of Legal Issues.” See Kd 14:8.1.2.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.6.eng: There are seven legitimate ways of acting according to what has been admitted. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.6.comm: Sp 5.327: Dhammikāpi tattheva niddiṭṭhā, “Legitimate: it is specified just there.” See Kd 14:8.2.2.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.7.eng: There is no offense in going for seven days to seven kinds of people. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.7.comm: Sp 5.327: Sattannaṁ anāpatti sattāhakaraṇīyena gantunti vassūpanāyikakkhandhake vuttaṁ, “There is no offense in going for seven days to seven kinds of people: it is spoken of in The Chapter on Entering the Rainy-season Residence.” See Kd 3:5.4.2 and Kd 3:7.2.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.8.eng: There are seven benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.8.comm: Sp 5.327: Sattānisaṁsā vinayadhareti “tassādheyyo uposatho pavāraṇā”ti imehi saddhiṁ pañcake vuttā pañca satta honti, “The seven benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law: the five mentioned in the fives together with the observance-day ceremony and the invitation ceremony being entrusted to them, making it seven.”

pli-tv-pvr7:96.9.eng: There are seven rules about ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.9.comm: Sp 5.327: Satta paramānīti chakke vuttāniyeva sattakavasena yojetabbāni, “The seven rules on ‘at the most’: what is spoken of in the sixes is to be constructed as a group of seven.” Sp-ṭ 5.327: Sattakesu chakke vuttāniyeva sattakavasena yojetabbānīti chakke vuttacuddasaparamāni dvidhā katvā dvinnaṁ sattakānaṁ vasena yojetabbāni, “In the sevens, what is spoken of in the sixes is to be constructed as a group of seven: having divided in two parts the fourteen ‘at the mosts’ spoken of in the sixes, it is to be constructed on account of two groups of seven.”

pli-tv-pvr7:96.10.eng: There is becoming subject to relinquishment at dawn on the seventh day. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.11.eng: There are seven principles for settling legal issues. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.12.eng: There are seven kinds of legal procedures. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.12.comm: The seven are: condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, not recognizing an offense, not making amends for an offense, and not letting go of a bad view. See Kd 11.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.13.eng: There are seven kinds of raw grain. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.15.eng: There are seven additions to the rule on eating in a group. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.16.eng: After being received, the tonics should be used from storage for at most seven days. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.17.eng: One takes a finished robe and leaves the monastery. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.17.comm: Sp 5.327: Katacīvarantiādīni dve sattakāni kathinakkhandhake niddiṭṭhāni, “A finished robe, etc.: the two groups of seven that are specified in The Chapter on the Robe-making Ceremony.” See Kd 7:2.1.0. This concerns the present and the next item.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.18.eng: One leaves the monastery with a finished robe. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.19.eng: A monk doesn’t have any offense he needs to recognize. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.19.comm: Sp 5.327: Bhikkhussa na hoti āpatti daṭṭhabbā, bhikkhussa hoti āpatti daṭṭhabbā, bhikkhussa hoti āpatti paṭikātabbāti imāni tīṇi sattakāni, dve adhammikāni, ekaṁ dhammikaṁ; tāni tīṇipi campeyyake niddiṭṭhāni, “A monk doesn’t have any offense he needs to recognize; a monk does have an offense he needs to recognize; a monk has an offense he needs to make amends for: for these three groups of seven, two are illegitimate, one is legitimate. These three are specified in The Chapter Connected with Campā.” See Kd 9:5.1.0. This comment refers to the present and the next two items.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.20.eng: A monk does have an offense he needs to recognize. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.21.eng: A monk has an offense he needs to make amends for. —
pli-tv-pvr7:96.21.comm: MS is faulty. I follow SRT and the commentary which have bhikkhussa hoti āpatti paṭikātabbā.

pli-tv-pvr7:96.22.eng: There are seven kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:96.23.eng: There are seven kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.

pli-tv-pvr7:97.1.eng: When a monk has seven qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:97.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:97.2.eng: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. And he undertakes and trains in the training rules. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant meditations of the higher mind. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:98.1.pli: Aparehipi sattahaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti—
pli-tv-pvr7:98.1.eng: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:98.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti tathārūpassa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:98.2.eng: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He has learned much, and he retains and accumulates what he has learned. Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—he has learned many such teachings, retained them in mind, recited them verbally, mentally investigated them, and penetrated them well by view. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant meditations of the higher mind. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:99.1.pli: Aparehipi sattahaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti—
pli-tv-pvr7:99.1.eng: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:99.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:99.2.eng: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail; he has analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant meditations of the higher mind. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:100.1.pli: Aparehipi sattahaṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu vinayadharo hoti—
pli-tv-pvr7:100.1.eng: When a monk has seven other qualities, he is an expert on the Monastic Law:

pli-tv-pvr7:100.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti; anāpattiṃ jānāti; lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti; garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti; anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṃsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṃvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe—“amutrāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṃ; tatrāpāsiṃ evaṃnāmo evaṅgotto evaṃvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno”ti iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati; dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti—“ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā, vacīduccaritena samannāgatā, manoduccaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ upavādakā, micchādiṭṭhikā, micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapannā, ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā, vacīsucaritena samannāgatā, manosucaritena samannāgatā, ariyānaṃ anupavādakā, sammādiṭṭhikā, sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapannā”ti iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti; āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:100.2.eng: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He recollects many past lives, that is, one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births; many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, many eons of both dissolution and evolution; and he knows: ‘There I had such a name, such a family, such an appearance, such food, such an experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan. Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere, and there I had such a name, such a family, such an appearance, such food, such an experience of pleasure and pain, and such a lifespan. Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’ In this way he recollects many past lives with their characteristics and particulars. (6) With superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell. But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly, at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’ In this way, with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, he sees beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and he understands how beings pass on according to their actions. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:101.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has seven qualities, he shines:

pli-tv-pvr7:101.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sīlavā hoti …pe… samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
pli-tv-pvr7:101.2.eng: (1) He knows the offenses. (2) He knows the non-offenses. (3) He knows the light offenses. (4) He knows the heavy offenses. (5) He is virtuous and restrained by the Monastic Code. His conduct is good, he associates with the right people, and he sees danger in minor faults. And he undertakes and trains in the training rules. (6) Whenever he wants, he accesses the four absorptions, those pleasant meditations of the higher mind. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:102.2.pli: āpattiṃ jānāti, anāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, garukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, bahussuto hoti …pe… diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdho catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ ābhicetasikānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṃ nikāmalābhī hoti akicchalābhī akasiralābhī, āsavānañca khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.

Those teachings that are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, that have a true goal and are well articulated, and that set out the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life—he has learned many such teachings, retained them in mind, recited them verbally, mentally investigated them, and penetrated them well by view. (7) And because of the ending of the corruptions, he has realized with his own insight, in this very life, the liberation by mind and the liberation by wisdom.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.1.pli: Aṭṭhānisaṃse sampassamānena na so bhikkhu āpattiyā adassane ukkhipitabbo.
pli-tv-pvr7:113.1.eng: “When you see eight benefits, you should not eject a monk for not recognizing an offense. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.2.pli: Aṭṭhānisaṃse sampassamānena paresampi saddhāya sā āpatti desetabbā.
pli-tv-pvr7:113.2.eng: When you see eight benefits, you should confess an offense even out of confidence in the others. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.3.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭha yāvatatiyakāti bhikkhūnaṁ terasake cattāro, bhikkhunīnaṁ sattarasake bhikkhūhi asādhāraṇā cattāroti aṭṭha, “The eight ‘after the third’: four among the thirteen for the monks and four among the seventeen for the nuns that are not in common with the monks, making eight.” This refers to the offenses entailing suspension.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.4.eng: There are eight ways of corrupting families. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.4.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭhahākārehi kulāni dūsetīti kulāni dūseti pupphena vā phalena vā cuṇṇena vā mattikāya vā dantakaṭṭhena vā veḷuyā vā vejjikāya vā jaṅghapesanikena vāti imehi aṭṭhahi, “The eight ways of corrupting families: one corrupts families with flowers, fruit, bath powder, soap, tooth cleaners, bamboo, medical treatment, or by taking messages on foot—with these eight.” See Bu Ss 13:2.8.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.5.eng: There are eight key phrases for the giving of robe-cloth. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.6.eng: There are eight key phrases for when the robe season comes to an end. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.7.eng: There are eight kinds of drinks. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.8.pli: Aṭṭhahi asaddhammehi abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto devadatto āpāyiko nerayiko kappaṭṭho atekiccho.
pli-tv-pvr7:113.8.eng: Because he was overcome and consumed by eight bad qualities, Devadatta is irredeemably destined to an eon in hell. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.11.eng: There are eight offenses entailing acknowledgment. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.12.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭhaṅgiko musāvādoti “vinidhāya sañña”nti iminā saddhiṁ pāḷiyaṁ āgatehi sattahīti aṭṭhahi aṅgehi aṭṭhaṅgiko, “Lying has eight factors: the seven found in the Canonical text together with this: ‘He misrepresents his perception’. It is eightfold because of eight factors.” For the first seven factors see Bu Pc 1:2.2.10.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.13.eng: The observance day has eight factors. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.13.comm: According to the commentary at Sp 5.328 this refers to the eight precepts.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.14.eng: There are eight qualities of a qualified messenger. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.15.eng: There are eight proper conducts of monastics of other religions. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.15.comm: See Kd 1:38.8.2–38.10.2. According to Sp 3.87, the last two items on this list counts as four separate practices, thus making eight in total.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.16.eng: The great ocean has eight amazing qualities. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.17.eng: This spiritual path has eight amazing qualities. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.20.eng: There is becoming subject to relinquishment at dawn on the eighth day. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.21.eng: There are eight offenses entailing expulsion. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.21.comm: This probably refers to the four offenses entailing expulsion for the monks, in addition to the four offenses entailing expulsion for the nuns that are not in common with the monks.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.22.eng: When she fulfills the eight parts, she should be expelled. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.22.comm: This refers to Bi Pj 8:2.1.33. The Pali actually says “the eighth part”, which in context means that all eight parts have been completed. For an explanation of the rendering “should be expelled” for nāsetabbā, see nāseti in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.23.pli: Aṭṭhamaṃ vatthuṃ paripūrentiyā desitāpi adesitā hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:113.23.eng: When she fulfills the eight parts, even if she confesses, it is not actually confessed. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.24.eng: There is full ordination with eight statements. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.24.comm: This refers to the full ordination of a nun, which happens before both Sanghas. The eight statements are the two motions and the six announcements.

pli-tv-pvr7:113.25.eng: One should stand up for eight people. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.25.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭhannaṁ paccuṭṭhātabbanti bhattagge vuḍḍhabhikkhunīnaṁ, “One should stand up for eight people: for the senior nuns in the dining hall.”

pli-tv-pvr7:113.26.eng: One should offer a seat to eight people. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.26.comm: Sp 5.328: Āsanampi tāsaṁyeva dātabbaṁ, “A seat should also be given to them.”

pli-tv-pvr7:113.27.eng: The female lay follower who asked for eight favors. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.28.eng: When a monk has eight qualities, he may be appointed as an instructor of the nuns. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.29.eng: There are eight benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.29.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭhānisaṁsā vinayadhareti pañcake vuttesu pañcasu “tassādheyyo uposatho, pavāraṇā, saṅghakamma”nti ime tayo pakkhipitvā aṭṭha veditabbā, “The eight benefits of being an expert on the Monastic Law: the eight are to be understood as the five mentioned in the fives and adding these three: the observance-day ceremony, the invitation ceremony, and legal procedures being entrusted to them.”

pli-tv-pvr7:113.30.eng: There are eight rules about ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:113.30.comm: Sp 5.328: Aṭṭha paramānīti pubbe vuttaparamāneva aṭṭhakavasena yojetvā veditabbāni, “There are eight rules on ‘at the most’: they are to be understood just as the previously mentioned ‘at the most’, having constructed it as a group of eight.”

pli-tv-pvr7:113.31.pli: Tassapāpiyasikākammakatena bhikkhunā aṭṭhasu dhammesu sammā vattitabbaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:113.31.eng: A monk who has had a legal procedure of further penalty done against himself should behave properly in eight respects. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.32.eng: There are eight kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:113.33.eng: There are eight kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.”

pli-tv-pvr7:120.2.eng: There are nine ways of getting rid of resentment. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.3.eng: There are nine grounds of training. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.3.comm: Sp 5.329: Nava vinītavatthūnīti navahi āghātavatthūhi ārati virati paṭivirati setughāto, “The nine grounds of training: the refraining from, the keeping away from, the desisting from, the incapability with respect to the nine grounds for resentment.”

pli-tv-pvr7:120.4.comm: The first nine offenses entailing suspension for monks.

pli-tv-pvr7:120.5.eng: The Sangha is split by a group of nine. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.7.eng: There is an offense of wrong conduct for eating nine kinds of meat. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.8.eng: There are nine ways of reciting the Monastic Code. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.8.comm: This probably refers to the five ways of reciting for monks, mentioned at Kd 2:15.1.4, together with the four ways of reciting for nuns, referred to at Pvr 2.1:1.8 and in the ensuing discussion.

pli-tv-pvr7:120.9.eng: There are nine rules about ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.9.comm: Sp 5.329: Nava paramānīti pubbe vuttaparamāneva navakavasena yojetvā veditabbāni, “There are nine rules on ‘at the most’: they are to be understood just as the previously mentioned ‘at the most’, having constructed it as a group of nine.”

pli-tv-pvr7:120.10.eng: There are nine things rooted in craving. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.11.eng: There are nine kinds of conceit. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.12.eng: There are nine kinds of robes that should be determined. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.13.eng: There are nine kinds of robes that should not be assigned to another. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.15.eng: There are nine illegitimate kinds of gifts. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.15.comm: Sp 5.329: Nava adhammikāni dānānīti saṅghassa pariṇataṁ aññasaṅghassa vā cetiyassa vā puggalassa vā pariṇāmeti, cetiyassa pariṇataṁ aññacetiyassa vā saṅghassa vā puggalassa vā pariṇāmeti, puggalassa pariṇataṁ aññapuggalassa vā saṅghassa vā cetiyassa vā pariṇāmetīti, “The nine illegitimate kinds of gifts: if it was intended for one sangha and he diverts it to another sangha or to a shrine or to an individual; if it was intended for one shrine and he diverts it to another shrine or to a sangha or to an individual; if it was intended for one individual and he diverts it to another individual or to a sangha or to a shrine.” This refers to Bu NP 30:2.26–2.28 and Bu Pc 82:2.2.4–2.2.6.

pli-tv-pvr7:120.16.eng: There are nine illegitimate kinds of receiving. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.16.comm: Sp 5.329: Nava paṭiggahaparibhogāti etesaṁyeva dānānaṁ paṭiggahā ca paribhogā ca, “The nine illegitimate kinds of receiving and possessions: the receiving and possession of these kinds of gifts.” This refers to the present and the next item.

pli-tv-pvr7:120.17.eng: There are nine illegitimate kinds of possession. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.18.pli: tīṇi dhammikāni dānāni, tayo dhammikā paṭiggahā, tayo dhammikā paribhogā.
pli-tv-pvr7:120.18.eng: There are three legitimate kinds of gifts, three legitimate kinds of receiving, and three legitimate kinds of possession. —
pli-tv-pvr7:120.18.comm: Sp 5.329: Tīṇi dhammikāni dānānīti saṅghassa ninnaṁ saṅghasseva deti, cetiyassa ninnaṁ cetiyasseva, puggalassa ninnaṁ puggalasseva detīti imāni tīṇi. Paṭiggahapaṭibhogāpi tesaṁyeva paṭiggahā ca paribhogā ca, “The three legitimate kinds of gift: inclining toward the Sangha, one gives to the Sangha, and inclining toward a shrine to a shrine. Inclining toward an individual, one gives to an individual. These are the three. Also receiving and possessions is the receiving and possession of these.”

pli-tv-pvr7:120.19.eng: There are nine illegitimate ways of winning over. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.20.eng: There are nine legitimate ways of winning over. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.21.eng: There are two groups of nine on illegitimate legal procedures. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.22.eng: There are two groups of nine on legitimate legal procedures. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.23.eng: There are nine kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:120.24.eng: There are nine kinds of legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code.”

pli-tv-pvr7:121.1.eng: The section on nines is finished.

pli-tv-pvr7:124.3.eng: Gifts, kinds of receiving, kinds of possession,

pli-tv-pvr7:125.1.eng: Illegitimate ways of winning over, and legitimate ways of winning over,

pli-tv-pvr7:125.2.eng: And twice two groups of nine;

pli-tv-pvr7:126.1.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa āghātavatthūnīti navakesu vuttāni nava “aṭṭhāne vā pana āghāto jāyatī”ti iminā saddhiṁ dasa honti, “The ten grounds for resentment: the ten are the nine spoken of in the nines together with this: one gives rise to resentment without reason.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.2.eng: There are ten ways of getting rid of resentment. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.2.comm: Sp 5.330: Āghātapaṭivinayāpi tattha vuttā nava “aṭṭhāne vā pana āghāto jāyati, taṁ kutettha labbhāti āghātaṁ paṭivinetī”ti iminā saddhiṁ dasa veditabbā, “The ten are to be understood as the nine ways of getting rid of resentment spoken of there together with this: one gives rise to resentment without reason, and one gets rid of it, thinking, ‘How will this help?’”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.3.eng: There are ten grounds of training. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.3.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa vinītavatthūnīti dasahi āghātavatthūhi viratisaṅkhātāni dasa, “The ten grounds of training: the ten are the abstaining from the ten grounds for resentment.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.4.eng: There are ten subject matters of wrong view. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.4.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasavatthukā micchādiṭṭhīti “natthi dinna”ntiādivasena veditabbā, “The ten subject matters of wrong view: they are to be understood on account of ‘there is nothing given’ etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.5.eng: There are ten subject matters of right view. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.5.comm: Sp 5.330: “Atthi dinna”ntiādivasena sammādiṭṭhi, “There is right view on account of ‘there is the given’ etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.6.comm: Sp 5.330: “Sassato loko”tiādinā vasena pana antaggāhikā diṭṭhi veditabbā, “The extreme views are to be understood on account of ‘the world is eternal’ etc.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.7.eng: There are ten kinds of wrongness. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.7.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa micchattāti micchādiṭṭhiādayo micchāvimuttipariyosānā, viparītā sammattā, “The ten kinds wrongness: wrong view, etc., ending with wrong liberation.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.8.eng: There are ten kinds of rightness. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.8.comm: Sp 5.330: Viparītā sammattā, “The kinds of rightness are the reverse.”

pli-tv-pvr7:126.9.eng: There are ten ways of doing unskillful deeds. —
pli-tv-pvr7:126.9.comm: For this and the next item see AN 10.211.

pli-tv-pvr7:126.10.eng: There are ten ways of doing skillful deeds. —

pli-tv-pvr7:126.11.eng: There are ten reasons why a vote is illegitimate. —

pli-tv-pvr7:126.12.eng: There are ten reasons why a vote is legitimate. —

pli-tv-pvr7:126.13.eng: There are ten training rules for novice monks. —

pli-tv-pvr7:126.14.eng: A novice monk who has ten qualities should be expelled.

pli-tv-pvr7:127.1.pli: Dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:127.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:127.2.pli: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ na uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ anuggahetvā adhammena kāreti, appaṭiññāya āpattiṃ na jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ na jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ na jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:127.2.eng: (1) he does not grasp what is proper for himself to say; (2) he does not grasp what is proper for others to say; (3-5) not grasping either, he makes them act illegitimately, without their admission; (6) he does not know the offenses; (7) he does not know the roots of the offenses; (8) he does not know the origin of the offenses; (9) he does not know the ending of the offenses; (10) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the offenses.
pli-tv-pvr7:127.2.comm: Here the punctuation of the Pali is wrong. The comma should come after appaṭiññāya, not before it; see Pvr 7:64.2.

pli-tv-pvr7:128.1.pli: Dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:128.1.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:128.2.pli: attano bhāsapariyantaṃ uggaṇhāti, parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ uggaṇhāti, attano bhāsapariyantaṃ uggahetvā parassa bhāsapariyantaṃ uggahetvā dhammena kāreti, paṭiññāya āpattiṃ jānāti, āpattiyā mūlaṃ jānāti, āpattisamudayaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhaṃ jānāti, āpattinirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:128.2.eng: (1) he grasps what is proper for himself to say; (2) he grasps what is proper for others to say; (3-5) grasping both, he makes them act legitimately, in accordance with their admission; (6) he knows the offenses; (7) he knows the roots of the offenses; (8) he knows the origin of the offenses; (9) he knows the ending of the offenses; (10) he knows the path leading to the ending of the offenses.

pli-tv-pvr7:129.1.pli: Aparehipi dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:129.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:129.2.pli: adhikaraṇaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇassa mūlaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇasamudayaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhaṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ na jānāti, vatthuṃ na jānāti, nidānaṃ na jānāti, paññattiṃ na jānāti, anupaññattiṃ na jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ na jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:129.2.eng: (1) he does not know the legal issues; (2) he does not know the roots of the legal issues; (3) he does not know the origin of the legal issues; (4) he does not know the ending of the legal issues; (5) he does not know the path leading to the ending of the legal issues; (6) he does not know the actions that are the bases for offenses; (7) he does not know the origin stories; (8) he does not know the rules; (9) he does not know the additions to the rules; (10) he does not know the sequence of statements.

pli-tv-pvr7:130.1.pli: Dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:130.1.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:130.2.pli: adhikaraṇaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇassa mūlaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇasamudayaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhaṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ jānāti, vatthuṃ jānāti, nidānaṃ jānāti, paññattiṃ jānāti, anupaññattiṃ jānāti, anusandhivacanapathaṃ jānāti.
pli-tv-pvr7:130.2.eng: (1) he knows legal issues; (2) he knows the roots of legal issues; (3) he knows the origin of legal issues; (4) he knows the ending of legal issues; (5) he knows the path leading to the ending of legal issues; (6) he knows the actions that are the bases for offenses; (7) he knows the origin stories; (8) he knows the rules; (9) he knows the additions to the rules; (10) he knows the sequence of statements.

pli-tv-pvr7:131.1.pli: Aparehipi dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:131.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:131.2.pli: ñattiṃ na jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ na jānāti, na pubbakusalo hoti, na aparakusalo hoti, akālaññū ca hoti, āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa na suggahitā hoti na sumanasikatā na sūpadhāritā.
pli-tv-pvr7:131.2.eng: (1) he does not know the motion; (2) he does not know how the motion is done; (3) he is not skilled in what comes first; (4) he is not skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he does not know the right time; (6) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (7) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (8) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (9) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (10) he has not well-learned or well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

pli-tv-pvr7:132.1.pli: Dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:132.1.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:132.2.pli: ñattiṃ jānāti, ñattiyā karaṇaṃ jānāti, pubbakusalo hoti, aparakusalo hoti, kālaññū ca hoti, āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ācariyaparamparā kho panassa suggahitā hoti sumanasikatā sūpadhāritā.
pli-tv-pvr7:132.2.eng: (1) he knows the motion; (2) he knows how the motion is done; (3) he is skilled in what comes first; (4) he is skilled in what comes afterwards; (5) he knows the right time; (6) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (7) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (8) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (9) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (10) he has well-learned and well-remembered his teachers’ tradition.

pli-tv-pvr7:133.1.pli: Aparehipi dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “bālo” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:133.1.eng: When an expert on the Monastic Law has ten other qualities, he is considered ignorant:

pli-tv-pvr7:133.2.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena na svāgatāni honti na suvibhattāni na suppavattīni na suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso, āpattānāpattiṃ na jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ na jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca na vinicchayakusalo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:133.2.eng: (1) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (3) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has not properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, not having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition; (6) he does not know the offenses and non-offenses; (7) he does not know the light and heavy offenses; (8) he does not know the curable and incurable offenses; (9) he does not know the grave and minor offenses; (10) he is not skilled in deciding legal issues.
pli-tv-pvr7:133.2.comm: The redundancy in this set seems to be a result of mechanically putting together two sets from the group of fives above. And the same below.

pli-tv-pvr7:134.1.pli: Dasahaṅgehi samannāgato vinayadharo “paṇḍito” tveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati—
pli-tv-pvr7:134.1.eng: But when an expert on the Monastic Law has ten qualities, he is considered learned:

pli-tv-pvr7:134.2.pli: āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, ubhayāni kho panassa pātimokkhāni vitthārena svāgatāni honti suvibhattāni suppavattīni suvinicchitāni suttaso anubyañjanaso, āpattānāpattiṃ jānāti, lahukagarukaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, sāvasesānavasesaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, duṭṭhullāduṭṭhullaṃ āpattiṃ jānāti, adhikaraṇe ca vinicchayakusalo hoti.
pli-tv-pvr7:134.2.eng: (1) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (2) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (3) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (4) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (5) he has properly learned both Monastic Codes in detail, having analyzed them well, thoroughly mastered them, and investigated them well, both in terms of the rules and their detailed exposition; (6) he knows the offenses and non-offenses; (7) he knows the light and heavy offenses; (8) he knows the curable and incurable offenses; (9) he knows the grave and minor offenses; (10) he is skilled in deciding legal issues.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.1.eng: A monk who has ten qualities may be appointed to a committee. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.2.pli: Dasa atthavase paṭicca tathāgatena sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.2.eng: The Buddha laid down the training rules for his disciples for ten reasons. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.3.eng: There are ten dangers of entering a royal compound. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.3.comm: See e.g. Bu Pc 83:1.3.1–1.3.53. For an explanation of the rendering “royal compound” for rājantepura, see antepura in Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.4.eng: There are ten reasons for giving. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.6.eng: A sangha of monks consisting of a group of ten. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.7.eng: A group of ten may give the full ordination. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.8.eng: There are ten kinds of rags. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.9.eng: There are ten kinds of robe wearing. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.9.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa cīvaradhāraṇāti “sabbanīlakāni cīvarāni dhārentī”ti vuttavasena dasāti kurundiyaṁ vuttaṁ. Mahāaṭṭhakathāyaṁ pana “navasu kappiyacīvaresu udakasāṭikaṁ vā saṅkaccikaṁ vā pakkhipitvā dasā”ti vuttaṁ, “The ten kinds of robe wearing: it is said in the Kurundī that the ten are on account of what was said: ‘They wore completely blue robes.’ But it is said in the Great Commentary that it is the nine allowable robes, adding the bathing robe or the chest wrap.” The former refers to Kd 8:29.1.1–29.1.11 and the nine allowable robes to Kd 8:20.2.2.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.10.eng: One should keep an extra robe for ten days at the most. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.11.eng: There are ten kinds of semen. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.12.eng: There are ten kinds of women. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.13.eng: There are ten kinds of wives. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.14.eng: The ten practices proclaimed as allowable at Vesālī. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.15.eng: There are ten kinds of people a monk should not pay respect to. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.16.eng: There are ten kinds of abuse. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.17.eng: There are ten ways of engaging in malicious talebearing. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.18.eng: There are ten kinds of furniture. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.18.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa senāsanānīti mañco, pīṭhaṁ, bhisi, bimbohanaṁ, cimilikā, uttarattharaṇaṁ, taṭṭikā, cammakhaṇḍo, nisīdanaṁ, tiṇasanthāro, paṇṇasanthāroti, “The ten kinds of furniture: a bed, a bench, a mattress, a pillow, a mat underlay, a bedspread, a straw-mat, a hide, a sitting mat, a spread of grass, a spread of leaves.” See Bu Pc 14:1.1.9.1 and Bu Pc 15:2.1.8. The ten kinds of furniture have become eleven in the commentary! Sp-yoj 5.330 helpfully adds: Paṇṇasanthāro tiṇasanthārena saṅgahito, “The spread of leaves is included in the spread of grass.” For an explanation of the rendering “furniture” for senāsana, see Appendix of Technical Terms.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.19.comm: Sp 5.330: Dasa varāni yāciṁsūti visākhā aṭṭha, suddhodanamahārājā ekaṁ, jīvako ekaṁ, “‘They asked for ten favors’: Visākhā eight, the great king Suddhodana one, Jīvaka one.”

pli-tv-pvr7:135.20.eng: There are ten kinds of illegitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.21.eng: There are the ten legitimate cancellations of the Monastic Code. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.22.eng: These are the ten benefits of congee. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.23.eng: There are ten kinds of unallowable meat. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.23.comm: See Kd 6:23.10.8–23.15.9 plus human meat as the tenth, see Kd 6:23.9.7.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.24.eng: There are ten rules on ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.24.comm: Ten out of the fourteen listed at Sp 5.326, see above at Pvr 7:81.9.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.25.pli: Dasavassena bhikkhunā byattena paṭibalena pabbājetabbaṃ upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇero upaṭṭhāpetabbo.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.25.eng: A competent and capable monk who has ten years of seniority may give the going forth, the full ordination, and formal support, and may have a novice monk attend on him. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.26.pli: Dasavassāya bhikkhuniyā byattāya paṭibalāya pabbājetabbaṃ upasampādetabbaṃ nissayo dātabbo sāmaṇerī upaṭṭhāpetabbā.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.26.eng: A competent and capable nun who has ten years of seniority may give the going forth, the full ordination, and formal support, and may have a novice nun attend on her. —
pli-tv-pvr7:135.26.comm: This and the next item contradict Bi Pc 74:1.14.1, which stipulates twelve years of seniority for a nun to give the full ordination.

pli-tv-pvr7:135.27.pli: Dasavassāya bhikkhuniyā byattāya paṭibalāya vuṭṭhāpanasammuti sāditabbā.
pli-tv-pvr7:135.27.eng: A competent and capable nun who has ten years of seniority may agree to be approved to give the full admission. —

pli-tv-pvr7:135.28.eng: The training may be given to a married girl who is ten years old.”

pli-tv-pvr7:136.1.eng: The section on tens is finished.

pli-tv-pvr7:138.3.eng: And kinds of wrongness, kinds of rightness,

pli-tv-pvr7:141.1.eng: Precious thing, and a group of ten,

pli-tv-pvr7:142.2.eng: Should not pay respect to, and with abuse;

pli-tv-pvr7:142.3.eng: And malicious talebearing, kinds of furniture,

pli-tv-pvr7:143.4.eng: The section on tens have been well proclaimed.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.1.pli: Ekādasa puggalā anupasampannā na upasampādetabbā, upasampannā nāsetabbā.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.1.eng: “There are eleven kinds of people who should not be ordained, and if they have been ordained, they should be expelled. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.1.comm: See Kd 1:61.1.19–68.1.4. A convenient list of the eleven is found at Khuddasikkhā-purāṇaṭīkā 16.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.2.eng: There are eleven kinds of unallowable shoes. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.2.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa pādukāti dasa ratanamayā, ekā kaṭṭhapādukā, “The eleven kinds of shoes: ten made with precious substances and one made of wood.” See the last ten items at Kd 5:8.3.4 and Kd 5:6.4.12.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.3.eng: There are eleven kinds of unallowable almsbowls. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.3.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa pattāti tambalohamayena vā dārumayena vā saddhiṁ dasa ratanamayā, “The eleven kinds of bowls: ten made with precious substances together with one made of copper or one made of wood.” See Kd 15:8.2.26–9.1.14. It is curious that the copper bowl is mentioned here as if separate from the list of ten, yet it also occurs in the list of ten. There seems to be an error either in the Canonical text or the commentary.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.4.eng: There are eleven kinds of unallowable robes. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.4.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa cīvarānīti sabbanīlakādīni ekādasa, “The eleven kinds of robes: the eleven are those that are entirely blue, etc.” See Kd 8:29.1.1–29.1.11.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.5.comm: Sp 5.331: Yāvatatiyakāti ukkhittānuvattikā bhikkhunī, saṅghādisesā aṭṭha, ariṭṭho, caṇḍakāḷīti, “‘After the third’: a nun takes sides with one who has been ejected, eight offenses entailing suspension, Ariṭṭha, and Caṇḍakāḷī.” This refers to Bi Pj 7:1.11.1, Bu Ss 10:1.3.16.1–13, Bi Ss 10:1.19.1–13, Bu Pc 68:1.49.1, and Bi Pc 36:1.11.1.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.6.eng: The nuns should be asked about the eleven obstacles. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.6.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa antarāyikā nāma “nasi animittā”ti ādayo, “The eleven obstacles: ‘Do you lack genitals? etc.” See Kd 20:17.1.6.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.7.eng: There are eleven kinds of robes that should be determined. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.7.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa cīvarāni adhiṭṭhātabbānīti ticīvaraṁ, vassikasāṭikā, nisīdanaṁ, paccattharaṇaṁ, kaṇḍuppaṭicchādi, mukhapuñchanacoḷaṁ, parikkhāracoḷaṁ, udakasāṭikā, saṅkaccikāti, “Eleven kinds of robes that should be determined: the three robes, the rainy-season robe, the sitting mat, a sheet, an itch-covering cloth, a washcloth, a cloth for requisites, the bathing robe, and the chest wrap.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.8.eng: There are eleven kinds of robes that should not be assigned to another. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.8.comm: Sp 5.331: Na vikappetabbānīti etāneva adhiṭṭhitakālato paṭṭhāya na vikappetabbāni, “Should not be assigned to another: beginning from the time of determination, these should not be assigned to another.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.9.eng: Becoming subject to relinquishment at dawn on the eleventh day. —

pli-tv-pvr7:144.10.eng: There are eleven kinds of allowable toggles. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.10.comm: Sp 5.331: Gaṇṭhikā ca vidhā ca suttamayena saddhiṁ ekādasa honti, te sabbe khuddakakkhandhake niddiṭṭhā, “Together with those made of thread, there are eleven kinds of toggles and buckles. They are all specified in The Chapter on Minor Topics.” For the toggles see Kd 15:29.3.12.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.11.eng: There are eleven kinds of allowable buckles. —

pli-tv-pvr7:144.12.eng: There are eleven kinds of unallowable earth. —

pli-tv-pvr7:144.13.eng: There are eleven kinds of allowable earth. —

pli-tv-pvr7:144.14.eng: There are eleven reasons why formal support comes to an end. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.14.comm: Sp 5.331: Nissayapaṭipassaddhiyo upajjhāyamhā pañca, ācariyamhā cha; evaṁ ekādasa, “The reasons why formal support comes to an end are five for a preceptor and six for a teacher, thus eleven.” See Kd 1:36.1.4 and Kd 1:36.1.7.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.15.eng: There are eleven kinds of people a monk should not pay respect to. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.15.comm: Sp 5.331: Avandiyapuggalā naggena saddhiṁ ekādasa, “The eleven are the people a monk should not pay respect to together with the naked person.” See respectively Kd 16:6.5.2 and Kd 15:15.1.4–15.1.7.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.16.eng: There are eleven rules on ‘at the most’. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.16.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa paramāni pubbe vuttesu cuddasasu ekādasakavasena yojetvā veditabbāni, “The eleven rules on ‘at the most’: they are to be understood among the previously mentioned fourteen, having constructed them as a group of eleven.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.17.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa varānīti mahāpajāpatiyā yācitavarena saddhiṁ pubbe vuttāni dasa, “The eleven favors: the ten spoken of previously together with the favor asked for by Mahāpajāpatī.” For the previous ten see above at Pvr 7:135.19. For the eleventh favor see Kd 20:3.1.3.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.18.eng: There are eleven kinds of flaws in monastery zones. —
pli-tv-pvr7:144.18.comm: Sp 5.331: Ekādasa sīmādosāti “atikhuddakaṁ sīmaṁ sammannantī”tiādinā nayena kammavagge āgamissanti, “The eleven flaws in monastery zones: ‘They approved a monastery zone that was too small,’ etc. They are handed down in ‘the subchapter on legal procedures’ through this method.” This is not a reference to Kd 11, but to Pvr 21:5.3.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.19.eng: There are eleven dangers to be expected for people who abuse and revile.

pli-tv-pvr7:144.20.pli: Mettāya cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ekādasānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā.
pli-tv-pvr7:144.20.eng: There are eleven benefits to be expected for one who practices the liberation of mind through love, who develops, cultivates, and makes it a vehicle and basis, who keeps it up, accumulates, and properly implements it:

pli-tv-pvr7:144.21.pli: Sukhaṃ supati, sukhaṃ paṭibujjhati, na pāpakaṃ supinaṃ passati, manussānaṃ piyo hoti, amanussānaṃ piyo hoti, devatā rakkhanti, nāssa aggi vā visaṃ vā satthaṃ vā kamati, tuvaṭṭaṃ cittaṃ samādhiyati, mukhavaṇṇo vippasīdati, asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, uttari appaṭivijjhanto brahmalokūpago hoti—
pli-tv-pvr7:144.21.eng: (1) you sleep well, (2) you wake up rested, and (3) you have no nightmares; (4) you are loved by humans and (5) spirits; (6) you are protected by the gods; (7) you cannot be harmed by fire, poison, or weapons; (8) your mind is quickly stilled; (9) your face is serene; (10) you die unconfused; and (11) if you do not go any further, you are reborn in the world of the supreme beings.”

pli-tv-pvr7:144.22.pli: mettāya cetovimuttiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime ekādasānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhāti.
